text: J U D G M E N T
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Police Inspector of Women Police Station Mysuru city has filed the charge sheet against accused for the offences punishable under sections 498 A R w section 34 of I P C Section 3 and 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act 2
label: FAC

text: The brief facts of the case of the prosecution are that The complainant and accused No 1 married on 09 07 2009 before the Sub Registrar at Mysuru and thereafter the said marriage was performed before the elders on 20 09 2010 at Kendaganneshwara temple
label: FAC

text: It is alleged in the complaint that the accused demanded for Rs 10 00 000 and gold ornaments
label: FAC

text: The parents of the complainant gave Rs 10 00 000 and other gold ornaments as per the demand
label: FAC

text: It is alleged that the accused No 1 to 3 started harassing the complainant for one or the other reason
label: FAC

text: The accused abused the complainant in filthy language
label: FAC

text: The complainant has alleged that the accused subjected her for physical assault
label: FAC

text: The accused demanded for further dowry amount from the complainant
label: FAC

text: Even after receipt of Rs 2 00 000 after the marriage the accused did not bother to take care of the complainant
label: FAC

text: It is also alleged that the accused demanded money for the purchase of Zen Car
label: FAC

text: The accused used to come to the place of work of the complainant and pick up quarrel with her
label: FAC

text: The complainant was driven out of the house and the gold and silver articles and the amount which was received as dowry by the accused was not returned to the complainant
label: FAC

text: Hence the complaint is lodged by the complainant against the accused No 1 to 4 before the concerned police
label: FAC

text: CW 12 has registered the case against the accused
label: FAC

text: CW 13 has further conducted the investigation and filed the charge sheet against the accused No 1 to 4 for offences punishable U s 498 A R w section 34 of I P C and Section 3 and 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act
label: FAC

text: 3 The accused No 1 to 4 are on Court bail
label: FAC

text: The charge framed read over and explained to the accused
label: FAC

text: After understanding the charge the accused denied the same and claimed to be tried
label: FAC

text: 4 The prosecution has examined PW 1 to 3 and the documents are marked as Ex P1 to P4
label: FAC

text: As there is no incriminating evidence against the accused the statement of accused U s 313 of Cr P C is dispensed with
label: ANALYSIS

text: 5 Heard arguments of Learned Assistant Public Prosecutor and counsel for accused
label: NONE

text: 6 The points that emerge for consideration are
label: ISSUE

text: 1 Whether the prosecution proves beyond reasonable doubt that the accused No 1 being the husband of CW 1 in furtherance of common intention has ill treated the complainant and the accused No 1 to 3 started harassing the complainant and abused the complainant in filthy language and he subjected her for physical assault also even after receipt of Rs 2 00 000 after the marriage the accused did not bother to take care of the complainant and the accused used to come to the place of work of the complainant and pick up quarrel with her the complainant was driven out of the house and thereby committed an offence punishable under section 498 A R w section 34 of I P C
label: ISSUE

text: 2 Whether the prosecution further proves beyond reasonable doubt that at the time of marriage the accused demanded for Rs 10 00 000 and gold ornaments and the parents of the complainant gave Rs 10 00 000 and other gold ornaments as per the demand and thereby committed an offence punishable under section 3 of Dowry Prohibition Act
label: ISSUE

text: 3 Whether the prosecution further proves beyond reasonable doubt that the accused harassed the complainant physically and mentally in demand of money and Even after receipt of Rs 2 00 000 after the marriage the accused did not bother to take care of the complainant and the accused demanded money for the purchase of Zen Car and thereby committed an offence punishable under section 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act
label: ISSUE

text: 4 What Order
label: ISSUE

text: 7 Perused oral and documentary evidence placed on record
label: NONE

text: Having heard the answer to above points are Point No 1 In the Negative Point No 2 Point No 3 In the Negative Point No 4 In the Negative As per final order below for the following R E A S O N S 8 POINT No 1 TO 3 The complainant Smt Nayana and her parents are examined on behalf of the prosecution as PW 1 to 3
label: ANALYSIS

text: 9 The contents of the complaint are that the complainant and the accused No 1 married on 09 07 2009 before the Sub Registrar Mysuru and thereafter the marriage was performed before the elders on 20 09 2010
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is alleged in the complaint that the complainant was tortured physically and mentally in demand of money by the accused No 1 to 4
label: ANALYSIS

text: The accused demanded for money to open a shop and a Gym center
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even after compliance of the dowwry the accused harassed the complainant
label: ANALYSIS

text: The accused demanded for Zen Car
label: ANALYSIS

text: The accused also caused harassment to the complainant in her work place
label: ANALYSIS

text: The evidence of PW 1 is totally contrary to the complaint
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW 1 has not deposed in accordance with the contents of the complaint
label: ANALYSIS

text: When the complainant turned hostile and not supported the case of the prosecution she was cross examined by the learned APP
label: ANALYSIS

text: 10 The PW 1 has admitted during the cross examination about the compromise held in between the complainant and the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: 11 PW 2 Sri Girigowda is the father of the complainant who turned hostile and not supported the case of the prosecution
label: ANALYSIS

text: 11 PW 3 Smt Pramila is the mother of the complainant who turned hostile and not supported the case of the prosecution
label: ANALYSIS

text: 12 The learned APP prayed to issue summons to the other witnesses but no purpose will be served in examining the other witnesses in view of the oral evidence given by the complainant before the Court of law
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence the prayer of learned APP was rejected and the case of the prosecution was closed
label: ANALYSIS

text: As there was no incriminating evidence the statement of accused U s 313 of Cr P C is also dispensed with
label: RATIO

text: 13 As per Sec 498 A of I P C husband or the relative of the husband who cause any ill treatment to the aggrieved woman are liable for the alleged offences
label: STA

text: But in view of the evidence of PW 1 to 3 the contents of the complaint are not supported
label: RATIO

text: Therefore the prosecution has failed to prove the guilt of the accused No 1 to 4 U s 498 A R w section 34 of I P C Section 3 and 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act
label: RATIO

text: Therefore the accused No 1 to 4 are entitle for acquittal
label: RATIO

text: Hence I answer Point No 1 to 5 in the Negative
label: NONE

text: 14 POINT No 6
label: RPC

text: In the result I proceed to pass the following O R D E R Acting U s 248 1 of Cr P C the accused No 1 to 4 are acquitted for the offences punishable under sections 498 A R w section 34 of I P C and section 3 and 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act
label: RPC

text: The bail bonds of the accused No 1 to 4 and their sureties stand cancelled
label: RPC

text: IN THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA AT BENGALURU
label: PREAMBLE

text: DATED THIS THE 20th DAY OF JANUARY 2015 PRESENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: THE HON BLE MR JUSTICE N KUMAR AND
label: PREAMBLE

text: THE HON BLE MR JUSTICE B VEERAPPA I T A NO 1047 2008 BETWEEN
label: PREAMBLE

text: 1 The Commissioner Of Income Tax C R Building Attavara Mangalore
label: PREAMBLE

text: 2 The Asst Commissioner APPELLANTS Of Income Tax Central Circle Mangalore
label: PREAMBLE

text: By Sri Jeevan J Neralagi Adv
label: PREAMBLE

text: AND Mr Manish Kumar Pajwani RESPONDENT M s Luck Associates 503 Kunil Centre Hampankatta Mangalore
label: PREAMBLE

text: By Sri A Shankar M Lava Advocates
label: PREAMBLE

text: This I T A is filed under Section 260A of the Income Tax Act 1961 arising out of order dated 30 06 2008 passed in IT SS A No 129 BNG 2004 for the Assessment year 01 04 1990 to 10 11 2000 praying to i formulate the substantial questions of law stated therein ii Allow the appeal and set aside the order passed by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal Bangalore in IT SS A No 129 BNG 2004 dated 30 06 2008 and confirm the order passed by Assessing Authority in the interest of justice
label: PREAMBLE

text: This I T A coming on for hearing this day N Kumar J delivered the following JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Revenue has preferred this appeal against the order passed by the Tribunal which has set aside the order passed by the Lower Authorities on the ground that the undisclosed income is to be assessed in the hands of the HUF insofar as the lottery business is concerned and insofar as the finance business is concerned it is to be assessed as AOP under the name Easy Finance and not under the name of the assessee in his individual capacity 2
label: RLC

text: The assessee is doing lottery business under the trade name M s Luck Associates Mangalore
label: FAC

text: He is also running unregistered finance business under the name and style of Easy Finance
label: FAC

text: A search as conducted on 10 11 2000 and a cash of Rs 8 00 000 was seized and gold jewellery weighing 430 grams was found
label: FAC

text: The assessee in his statement stated that the main stockists of lottery were M s Pooja Agencies and M s Ganesh Agencies of Delhi M s Sri Laxmi Venkatesh Lottery Mangalore and M s M Co Bangalore
label: FAC

text: The Assessing Authority passed an order on 29 11 2002 under Section 158BC read with Section 143 3 of the Income tax Act 1961 for short hereinafter referred to as the Act
label: FAC

text: The Assessing Authority did not accept the case of the assessee and held that the undisclosed income offered has to be assessed in the name of the assessee in his individual capacity in respect of both lottery business and finance business
label: FAC

text: Aggrieved by the said order the assessee preferred an appeal to the Commissioner of Income tax Appeals who affirmed the said order
label: FAC

text: Thereafter the Assessee preferred a second appeal to the Tribunal
label: FAC

text: 3 The Tribunal on consideration of the entire material on record took note of the fact that the assessee s father by name Harshad Rai Pajwani has got HUF registered under the provisions of the Sales tax on 02 08 1999
label: FAC

text: However he died on 16 10 1999
label: FAC

text: Thereafter the son carried on the said lottery business as kartha of the HUF
label: FAC

text: Therefore the Tribunal was of the view that the authorities were not justified in assessing the undisclosed income relatable to the lottery business in the hands of the individual but it ought to be assessed in the hands of the HUF
label: RLC

text: Insofar as the finance business is concerned it was done under the name of Easy Finance
label: RLC

text: The seized materials show the names of Prakash Rajesh and Jagadish who are the members of the association
label: FAC

text: In fact the notice was issued to AOP
label: FAC

text: In those circumstances the Tribunal was of the view that even the undisclosed income relating to the finance business have to be assessed in the hands of AOP and not in the hands of the assessee in his individual capacity
label: RLC

text: Accordingly it allowed the appeal set aside the impugned orders and accepted the case of the assessee
label: RLC

text: 4 Aggrieved by the said order the Revenue is in appeal
label: FAC

text: This appeal was admitted to consider the following substantial questions of law i Whether in the facts and circumstances of the case the Tribunal was right in deleting the addition of income from lottery business in the hands of the assessee treating it as HUF s income and not the assessee on the basis of the Sales Tax Returns filed ii Whether the Tribunal was right in deleting the addition made representing the assessed income from finance business by holding that it represented the income of AOP solely on the basis of investment made in finance business when factually no AOP existed
label: ISSUE

text: 5 We have heard the learned counsel appearing for the parties
label: NONE

text: 6 Insofar as the first substantial question of law is concerned whether the undisclosed income relatable to particularly the lottery business is to be assessed in the hands of the individual or HUF is purely a question of fact
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Tribunal has taken note of the undisputed fact that the father of the assessee got registered the HUF under the provisions of the Sales Tax on 02 08 1999 which is not in dispute
label: ANALYSIS

text: It shows that the father wanted to do lottery business as HUF
label: ANALYSIS

text: Unfortunately within two months there from that is on 16 10 1999 the father died
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is the case of the assessee that he continued the said business as the Kartha of the HUF
label: ANALYSIS

text: The reason given by the Lower Authorities to come to the conclusion that the amount is to be assessed in the hands of the assessee as an individual instead of HUF is that the HUF did not have money to invest in this business as they have not maintained any accounts
label: ANALYSIS

text: The said inference drawn by the assessing authority is without any basis
label: ANALYSIS

text: As is clear from the aforesaid facts the sales tax registration was done on 02 08 1999 and within two months the father died
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore the question of the father maintaining the books of accounts would not arise
label: ANALYSIS

text: After the death of the father the son is carrying on with the said business
label: ANALYSIS

text: If he had maintained the accounts and if he had disclosed all the amounts in the accounts it seems that it would not have been treated as undisclosed income
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is because books were not maintained and returns were not filed the authorities laid their hands on the undisclosed income
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore the Tribunal was justified in the facts of the case in holding that the said amount is to be assessed in the hands of the HUF in the aforesaid circumstances and not in the hands of the assessee in his individual capacity
label: ANALYSIS

text: In fact during such proceedings the assessee had requested the authorities to adjust this undisclosed income and seized cash as advance tax for HUF and therefore we do not find any infirmity in the order passed by the Tribunal which calls for interference
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence we answer the first substantial question of law in favour of the assessee and against the Revenue
label: ANALYSIS

text: 7 Insofar as the second substantial question of law is concerned it is not in dispute that the seized materials disclose the names of the three persons namely Manish Jagadish and Rajesh
label: ANALYSIS

text: They were carrying on the finance business under the name and style of Easy Finance as Association of Persons
label: ANALYSIS

text: 8 In fact the notice under Section 158BC of the Act was issued in the capacity as AOP only on 08 11 2002
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even before issue of that notice returns had been filed in the status of AOP and the tax had been paid
label: ANALYSIS

text: The returns filed by the assessee on 24th August 2001 for all the three years from 1999 2000 2000 2001 and 2001 2002 shows undisclosed income as Nil
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the light of the aforesaid evidence on record the undisclosed income relatable to the finance business is to be assessed in the hands of the AOP and not as an individual
label: RPC

text: Thus second substantial question of law is answered in favour of the assessee and against the Revenue
label: RPC

text: 9 For the aforesaid reasons we do not see any merit in this appeal
label: RPC

text: Appeal is dismissed
label: RPC

text: Sd JUDGE Sd JUDGE SPS
label: NONE

text: PETITIONER STATE OF MADRAS Vs RESPONDENT T NARAYANASWAMI NAIDU AND ANR DATE OF JUDGMENT 12 04 1967 BENCH SIKRI S M
label: PREAMBLE

text: BENCH SIKRI S M SHAH J C RAMASWAMI V CITATION 1968 AIR 194 1967 SCR 3 622 1 CITATOR INFO R 1987 SC2244 ACT Madras General Sales Tax Act 9 of 1939 Ss 3 and 4 Goods in stock Liability to tax as last purchase HEADNOTE The assessee a dealer in cotton claimed deduction of Sales tax on the ground that cotton worth that value were in stock on the last day of the assessing year
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Commercial Tax Officer disallowed the claim holding that as subsequent disposal had not been proved it was liable to be taxed as a last purchase
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Assistant Commissioner upheld the order but the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal accepted the assessee s
label: PREAMBLE

text: claim
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Department s revision to the High Court was dismissed
label: PREAMBLE

text: In to this Court HELD The assessee was not liable till the purchase of declared goods acquired the character of a last purchase within the Second Schedule of the Act It is true that Ss 3 and 4 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act speak of a year i e the financial year and it is only the turnover during that year that is liable to taxation in the hands of the assessee but s 4 has to be read with the Second Schedule and reading s 4 with the Second Schedule it is
label: PREAMBLE

text: clear that a dealer is not liable to pay a tax on the purchases until the Purchases acquire the quality of being last purchases inside the State
label: PREAMBLE

text: In other words when he files a return and declares the stock in hand the stock in hand cannot be said to have been acquired by last purchase because he may still during the next assessment year sell it or he may consume it himself or the goods may be destroyed etc
label: PREAMBLE

text: He would be entitled to claim before the assessing authorities that the character of acquisition of the stock in hand was undetermined in the light of subsequent events it may or may not become the last purchase inside the State
label: PREAMBLE

text: This construction is in consonance with s 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act 1956
label: PREAMBLE

text: 625E G Abdulsalan Rowther v State of Kerala 12 S T C 98 and Hornusji Hirjiblioy v Commercial Tax Of 113 S T C 773 referred to
label: PREAMBLE

text: JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals No s 633 634 of 1966 Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 11 1964 of the Madras High Court in Tax Cases Nos 105 and 125 of 1963 Revision Nos 64 and 81
label: NONE

text: G Ramanujam and A V Rangam for the appellant in both the appeals
label: NONE

text: S T Desai and G L Sanghi for the respondents in both the appeals
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sikri J
label: NONE

text: These appeals by special leave are directed against the judgment of the Madras High Court in Tax Cases Nos 105 and 125 of 1963
label: RLC

text: The High Court by its common judgment dated August 11 1964 confirmed the orders of the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal
label: RLC

text: A common point of law is involved in both the cases and it will suffice if we give facts in Tax Case No 105 of 1963 Civil Appeal Nos 633 of 1966 in which the respondent was one T Narayanaswami Naidu hereinafter referred to as the assessee
label: FAC

text: The assessee is a dealer in cotton and cotton seeds
label: FAC

text: Before the Additional Commercial Tax Officer Coimbatore he claimed to deduct the sum of Rs 12 32 756 45 as the value of purchases other than the last purchases of cotton
label: FAC

text: The Commercial Tax Officer exempted Rs 10 11 534 40 but disallowed the remaining amount on the ground that cotton worth Rs 2 27 250 00 was in stock on March 31 1961
label: FAC

text: He found that subsequent disposal in the next year had not been proved and therefore it was liable to be taxed as a last purchase
label: FAC

text: In holding this he followed the decision of the Kerala High Court in Abdulsalam Rowther v State of Kerala 1
label: FAC

text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner Commercial Taxes upheld the order but the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal dissenting from the decision of the Kerala High Court in Abdulsalam Rowther v State of Kerala 1 accepted the appeal of the assessee and demanded the ease to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner for disposal afresh in the light of observations made by it
label: RLC

text: The Department filed a revision under s 38 of tile Madras General Sales Tax Act hereinafter referred to as the Madras Act and the High Court dismissed the revision
label: RLC

text: The State of Madras having obtained special leave the appeal is now before us
label: FAC

text: The learned counsel for the appellant Mr Ramanujam urges that the decision of the Kerala High Court in Abdulsalam Rowthel v State of Kerala 1 and of the Mysore High Court in Hornusji Hirjibhoy v Conmmercial Tax Officer 2 laid down the law correctly and the Madras High Court erred in dissenting from these decisions in the present case now reported as State of Madras v T Narayanaswami Naidu 3 Section 4 of the Madras Act provides
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 4 Notwithstanding anything contained in section 3 the tax under this Act shall be payable by a dealer on the sale or purchase inside the State of declared goods at the rate and only at the point specified against each in the Second Schedule on the turnover in such goods in each year whatever be the quantum of turnover in that year
label: STA

text: In other words this section lays down that in respect of declared goods we have to look at the Second Schedule in order to find 1 12 S T C 98 3 16 S T C 29 2 13 S T C 773 out the point at which the tax would be payable by the dealer
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Second Schedule describes the declared goods in respect of which a single point tax only is leviable under s 4
label: ANALYSIS

text: Item 2 of the Second Schedule is Cotton that is to say all kinds of cotton indigenous or imported in its unmanufactured state whether ginned or unginned baled pressed or otherwise but excluding cotton waste
label: ANALYSIS

text: The point of levy is stated as at the point of last purchase in the State
label: ANALYSIS

text: The question that arises is what is the exact meaning of the expression at the point of last purchase in the State
label: ISSUE

text: In this connection it may be mentioned that S 14 of the Central Sales lax Act 1956 hereinafter referred to as the Central Act declares certain goods as of special importance in inter State trade and commerce and cotton is one of the goods included in s 14
label: ANALYSIS

text: Section 15 provides 15
label: STA

text: Every sales tax law of a State shall in so far as it imposes or authorises the imposition of a tax on the sale or purchase of declared goods be subject to the following restrictions and conditions namely a the tax payable under that law in respect of any sale or purchase of such goods inside the State shall not exceed two per cent of the sale or purchase price thereof and such tax shall not be levied at more than one stage
label: STA

text: Section 4 of the Madras Act was intended to comply with s 15 of the Central Act
label: ANALYSIS

text: The relevant portion of s 3 of the Madras Act on which the learned counsel for the appellant relies provides 3 1 Every dealer other than a casual trader or agent of a non resident dealer whose total turnover for a year is not less than ten thousand rupees and every casual trader or agent of a non resident dealer whatever be his turnover for the year shall pay a tax for each year at the rate of two per cent of his taxable turnover I Section 2 p defines taxable turnover to mean the turnover on which a dealer shall be liable to pay tax as determined after making such deductions from his total turnover and in such manner as may be prescribed and year is defined to mean financial year
label: STA

text: Turnover is defined in S 2 r as follows turnover means the aggregate amount for which goods are bought or sold or supplied or distributed by a dealer either directly or through another on his own account or on account of others whether for cash or for deferred payment or other valuable consideration provided that the proceeds of the sale by a person of agricultural or horticultural produce other than tea grown within the State by himself or on any land in which he has an interest whether as owner usufructuary mortgagee tenant or otherwise shall be excluded from his turnover
label: STA

text: The learned counsel for the appellant says that it is clear from ss 3 and 4 that a tax under the Madras Act is a yearly tax
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: In other words he says that just as under the Indian Income Tax Act each assessment year is a self contained unit so is the assessment year a self contained unit under the Madras Act
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: If that is so he argues then what happens in subsequent year cannot be taken into consideration for determining the taxability of any purchase inside the State of declared goods
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He says that the taxable event is the last purchase in the State during the assessment year and if stocks are held at the end of the assessment year it follows that the assessee holding the stocks is the last purchaser in the State
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: In our opinion this reasoning is fallacious
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is true that ss 3 and 4 speak of a year i e the financial year and it is only the turnover during that year that is liable to taxation in the hands of the assessee but s 4 has to be read with the Second Schedule and reading s 4 with the Second Schedule it seems to us clear that a dealer is not liable to pay a tax on the purchases until the purchases acquire the quality of being the last purchases inside the State
label: ANALYSIS

text: In other words when he files a return and declares the stock in hand the stock in hand cannot be said to have been acquired by last purchase because he may still during the next assessment year sell it or he may consume it himself or the goods may be destroyed etc
label: ANALYSIS

text: He would be entitled to claim before the assessing authorities that the character of acquisition of the stock in hand was undetermined in the light of subsequent events it may or may not become The last purchase inside the State
label: ANALYSIS

text: In our view this construction is in consonance with s 15 of the Central Act
label: ANALYSIS

text: If the argument of the learned counsel for the State were to be accepted it would mean that the States could with impunity levy purchase tax on declared goods at more than one stage i e on purchases in the hands of one dealer during one assessment year and purchases of the same goods in the hands of another dealer in a subsequent assessment year and so on
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore we agree with the Madras High Court that the assessee is right in contending that he was entitled to claim deduction in respect of the value of the stock of Rs 2 27 250 as being the purchases other than last purchases of cotton
label: ANALYSIS

text: L7 Sup Cl 67 1 0The Kerala High Court in Abdulsalam Rowther v State of Kerala 1 following certain cases decided under the Income Tax Act was influenced by the consideration that an assessee could not rely on subsequent events in order to escape taxation
label: PRE_RELIED

text: That may be so even under the Sales Tax Act but according to our view the assessee is not liable till the purchase of declared goods acquires the character of a last purchase within the Second Schedule referred to above
label: ANALYSIS

text: In Hornusji Hirjibhoy v Commercial Tax Officer 1 the Mysore High Court also seems to have been impressed by similar considerations
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The judgment under appeal draws a distinction between tax able event and a stage at which the levy of tax in the case of declared goods is subject to single point levy
label: ANALYSIS

text: This may cause confusion and indeed the High Court gives one illustration which it found unnecessary to deal with
label: ANALYSIS

text: The illustration given is One can visualise a case for example where goods mentioned above purchased on the 30th of March 1960 may be exported by the purchaser himself outside the State on the 2nd of April 1960
label: ANALYSIS

text: In that case the goods could not be assessed in 1960 61 in the hands of the exporting purchaser because the taxable event did not occur in that year it could not be assessed in the hands of the seller in 1959 60 because though the taxable event occurred that year the single point stage was not reached in that year
label: ANALYSIS

text: One possible way of dealing with such a case is to assess it subsequently as escaped turnover
label: ANALYSIS

text: In our opinion in this illustration the assessee would be liable in the financial year 1960 61 as the purchases became the last purchases in that year
label: RPC

text: In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs
label: RPC

text: The facts in Tax Case No 125 of 1963 Civil Appeal No 634 of 1966 are similar
label: RPC

text: That appeal is also dismissed with costs
label: RPC

text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner Commercial Taxes will now dispose of the cases remanded to him by the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal in the light of the judgment
label: RPC

text: Y P
label: RPC

text: Appeal dismissed
label: RPC

text: In the Court of I Addl Civil Judge Sr Dn Mysore
label: PREAMBLE

text: Present Smt H R Radha B A L LL B
label: PREAMBLE

text: I Addl
label: PREAMBLE

text: Civil Judge Sr Dn Mysore
label: PREAMBLE

text: Date of Judgment 03 10 2009 Appellant R A 299 2007 G Suresh S o Gurappa Aged about 46 years No 2788 1 14th cross Basaveshwara Road Mysore By Sri Krishnaswamy C Advocate Vs Respondents 1 Fathimunnissa D o Sabina Parvin Aged about 18 years
label: PREAMBLE

text: 2 Kum
label: PREAMBLE

text: Hazira D o Sabina Parvina
label: PREAMBLE

text: Aged about 11 years 2nd respondent is a minor
label: PREAMBLE

text: Represented by her next Friend and natural guardian mother residing at No 1585 9th cross 4th main Vivekananda Circle Mysore By Sri T N Ramesh Advocate Date and nature of decree Judgement and decree
label: PREAMBLE

text: in O S 583 2004 dated or order appealed against 9 8 2007 passed by the Learned III Addl Civil Judge Jr Dn Mysore Date of institution of Appeal 25 08 2007 Duration of the appeal Year Month Days 2 1 9 REGULAR APPEAL NO 231 2005 JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: This is the plaintiff s appeal is filed U o IXL Rule 1 CPC against dismissal of his suit in O S 583 2004 for declaration and permanent injunction by the Court of III Addl Civil Judge Jr Dn Mysore vide Judgment and decree dated 09 08 2007 2
label: RLC

text: The parties are referred as per their original rank before the trial court for the sake of convenience
label: FAC

text: 3 It is the plaintiff s case that he belongs to lingayath community and a Hindu by religion
label: FAC

text: On 07 03 1990 he married Annapurna according to Hindu customs and traditions and has two Kum Shushma and Karthik in the said wed lock
label: FAC

text: The mother of the defendants filed C Mis 135 2000 U s 125 Cr P C before the Family Court at Mysore seeking maintenance from him
label: FAC

text: The family court gave a specific finding that the mother of the defendants is not his legally wedded wife of the plaintiff but he was ordered to pay maintenance to the defendants herein
label: RLC

text: His revision before the Hon ble High Court of Karnataka in RPFC No 8 2004 came to be dismissed with an observation that the order passed by the Family court is interim in nature and would be in force till a declaration is given by a competent civil court
label: RLC

text: Left with no other alternative he filed this suit for declaration and injunction
label: FAC

text: 4 The defendants represented by their mother contend in the written statement that their mother Sabeena Parveen is the legally wedded wife of the plaintiff and they are born to the plaintiff in the said wed lock
label: FAC

text: In C Mis 135 2000 it is held that they are the children of the plaintiff born to Sabina Parveen
label: FAC

text: The Hon ble High Court of Karnataka has also upheld the decision of the Family Court
label: RLC

text: To forestall the recovery proceedings the plaintiff has filed this suit on frivolous grounds
label: RLC

text: The plaintiff had married Sabeena Parveen according to Hindu Customs on 21 03 1988 at Ganesha temple Mysore by exchanging garlands and tying Mangalasutra
label: RLC

text: The plaintiff developed bad habits after the birth of 1st defendant and used to beat Sabeena Parveen he even intentionally deserted them
label: RLC

text: He threw Sabeen Parveen from the matrimonial home after she refused to give him divorce
label: RLC

text: 5 Basing on the above pleadings the Trial Court has framed the following ISSUES 1
label: FAC

text: Whether the plaintiff is entitled for declaration to the effect that there is no relation of father and children between the plaintiff and the defendants
label: FAC

text: 2 Whether the plaintiff is entitled to the relief of permanent injunction restraining the defendants from enforcing the order passed by the Hon ble Judge Family Court Mysore in C Mis No 135 2000 dated 10 12 2003
label: FAC

text: 3 Whether this court has no jurisdiction to entertain the suit
label: FAC

text: 4 What order or decree
label: FAC

text: 6 The plaintiff and his three witnesses have been examined as PW1 to PW4 Ex P1 to Ex P18 and Ex P4 a Ex P6 a have been marked for the plaintiff
label: FAC

text: The defendants mother and natural guardian has examined herself as DW1 and got marked Ex D1 to Ex D12 7
label: FAC

text: After considering all the materials placed on record and the evidence adduced by the parties the trial court dismissed the suit by judgment and decree dated 09 08 2007
label: RLC

text: Aggrieved by the same the plaintiff has preferred this appeal on the following amongst other grounds That the Trial Court has failed to appreciate the oral and documentary evidence adduced by him in proper perspective Ex P3 has been rejected on some flimsy grounds and the Trial court failed to note that DW1 is not an illiterate lady and she had attested her signature in English
label: FAC

text: The evidence of PW2 is also not appreciated properly
label: FAC

text: The Trial Court erred in relying upon Ex P15 P17 and Ex P18 in as much as particulars therein are not given by him
label: FAC

text: 8 The Learned Counsel for the appellant has filed written arguments
label: ANALYSIS

text: I have gone through the same carefully and thoroughly
label: ANALYSIS

text: I have also given my anxious consideration to the arguments advanced by the learned Counsel for the appellant and also the respondents
label: ANALYSIS

text: I have carefully gone through the oral and documentary evidence adduced by the parties before the Trial Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: 9 The points that arise for my consideration are 1 Whether the findings of the Trial Court on issue No 1 is just and sustainable 2 Whether impugned Judgment and decree calls for interference
label: ISSUE

text: 3 What order
label: ISSUE

text: 10 My findings on the above Points are Point No 1 In the Affirmative
label: ANALYSIS

text: Point No 2 In the Negative
label: ANALYSIS

text: Point No 3 As per final order for following REASONS 11
label: ANALYSIS

text: Point No 1
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The Learned Counsel appearing for the appellant vehemently canvassed that the plaintiff who is a Lingayath is married to Annapurna and has got two children in the said wed lock
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The Family Court while disposing of the C Mis filed by the defendants mother held that the she is not the legally wedded wife of the plaintiff
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The Trail Court erred in not properly appreciating Ex P3 sworn to by DW1 and produced before the school authorities seeking change of the defendants father s name as Yusuf in the place of Suresh
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: DNA test was not done to confirm the paternity
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 12 Per contra the Learned Counsel for the respondents supported the judgment and decree of the Trial Court
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: It was contended by him that since the plaintiff has not chosen to assail the judgment in RPFC 8 2004 the finding that the defendants are the children of the plaintiff has become final
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: In Ex P3 a printed Form there is a huge blank space between the typed matter and DW1 s signature which is not even identified by anybody
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Merely because the signature is affixed in English it cannot be presumed that DW1 is a literate
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Ex P3 is a concocted document
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: 13 In the light of the above rival contentions if the evidence on record is carefully examined it is seen that the question whether PW1 is married to Annapurna and has children through her is irrelevant for the purpose of this case
label: ANALYSIS

text: The trial court thus has rightly held that the Ex P7 to Ex P13 are not material to the matter in issue
label: ANALYSIS

text: 14 Further the findings of the Family Court in C Mis 135 00 that the mother of the defendants is not the legally wedded wife of the plaintiff has reached finality as the said order is confirmed by the Hon ble High Court of Karnataka in RPFC No 8 2004
label: ANALYSIS

text: Further no relief is claimed against her in the suit filed by the plaintiff
label: ANALYSIS

text: 15 The only issue that requires to be considered is whether the defendants are the children of the plaintiff or not
label: ANALYSIS

text: The plaintiff to discharge the burden cast upon him relies mainly on Ex P3 which is an affidavit sworn to by Sabeena Parveen for change of her husband s name in the school records Yousuf on the ground that it is wrongly entered as Suresh in respect of her daughter Fathimmunnisa
label: ANALYSIS

text: 16 On perusal of Ex P3 it is seen that there is a huge gap between the typed portion and DW1 s signature which is not even identified by any Advocate
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex P3 is said to have been sworn to before certain S Sundararaja Iyengar a Notary on 24 7 1997
label: ANALYSIS

text: DW1 categorically states that the plaintiff admitted Fathimunnisa to C K C Convent and that she has not appeared before any Notary on 24 07 1997 17
label: ANALYSIS

text: No doubt Ex P6 report of the expert commissioner is to the effect that the signature of DW1 on Ex P3 is the same as the one found on the vakalathnama and the written statement filed by DW1 on behalf of minor defendants in this case
label: ANALYSIS

text: DW1 specifically states that the name of the first defendant s father as seen in the birth certificate Ex P5 was entered as instructed by the plaintiff
label: ANALYSIS

text: 18 Ex D1 is the Certificate issued by Christ Convent 30 1 2003 to the effect that the 1st defendant is the daughter of G Suresh i e the plaintiff and that she is a student of their Institution her date of birth is 15 9 1990 as per the school records
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex D9 is the Antenatal Card issued by the Dr B Nirmala a Consultant Gynecologist wherein DW1 s husband s name is shown as Suresh
label: ANALYSIS

text: DW1 has stated that this document pertains to the 1st defendant
label: ANALYSIS

text: 19 Ex
label: ANALYSIS

text: D10 is the birth certificate in respect of the 1st defendant wherein the name of her parents is shown as Suresh and Sabeena
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex D11 is the voters list extract obtained on 3 3 94 wherein the plaintiff and DW1 are shown as husband and wife
label: ANALYSIS

text: DW1 claims that the plaintiff at the relevant point of time furnished these particulars
label: ANALYSIS

text: 20 PW1 pleads ignorance to the suggestion that the 2nd defendant Hazira was born while he was living with DW1 in Vivekanandanagara
label: ANALYSIS

text: He also claims to be not knowing the contents of Ex P3 and if the signature thereon is not made by DW1
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW1 says that he does not know who handed over Ex P3 to School authorities
label: ANALYSIS

text: 21 PW2 H M of C K C Convent unequivocally admits that in Ex P2 the 1st defendant s father s name is entered as G Suresh and even in the application submitted at the time of her admission it was mentioned so
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to PW2 only during 2004 on the basis of Ex P3 she has struck off Suresh in Ex P5 and changed it as Yusuf that after the plaintiff brought filing of such affidavit to her knowledge
label: ANALYSIS

text: The relevant portion of PW2 s evidence reads as under zj Cqm 2004 g UģP ýzU Agvz B13 1 2005 gAz Ai zj AiĪ UģP vAgvg 3 C U Aiig vAz Pngvg JAz U Uwۮ zj wzݥr iqĪ Aiz zj wzݥr AiĪ 1 wUU Cx Cg vAi UģPU vg 3 C x jU PýzU rzã 22
label: ANALYSIS

text: Further PW2 states that she does not know who effected corrections in Ex P6 which was admittedly issued on 10 4 2000 much prior to PW2 noticing Ex P3
label: ANALYSIS

text: How the plaintiff came to know about existence of Ex P3 remains unanswered
label: ANALYSIS

text: 23 Ex D5 is NCR issued by the SHO of Ashokapuram Police Station Mysore to DW1 in respect of a complaint against her husband Suresha
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex D8 is the endorsement issued on 1 7 2000 with respect to this complaint
label: ANALYSIS

text: If at all the plaintiff was not at all known to DW1 as claimed how DW1 could give his name as her husband s name or lodge a complaint against him as early as in 1990 and year 2000
label: ANALYSIS

text: has also remained unanswered
label: ANALYSIS

text: 24 On perusal Ex P14 it is seen that the Family Court had held that the plaintiff herein and DW1 though were residing together as husband and wife yet DW1 could not be his legally wedded wife on account of the fact that she had remained a Muslim
label: ANALYSIS

text: This finding has not bee set aside varied or modified by the Hon ble High Court of Karnataka in RPFC No 8 2004
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore the same has reached finality
label: ANALYSIS

text: 25 The evidence on record indicates that PW2 on being prompted by the plaintiff has struck off the plaintiff s name appearing in the 1st defendant s school records without intimating the defendants or their mother
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex P3 is dated 24 7 1997 but PW2 has acted upon the same somewhere during the year 2005
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore it appears that on account of his strained relationship with DW1 the plaintiff has engineered changes in the entries made in the school records
label: ANALYSIS

text: 26 Ex P15 17 and 18 are issued by the statutory authorities such as Election Commission City Corporation Mysore and these documents speak to the effect that the plaintiff and DW1 were residing together as husband and wife and the 1st defendant was born to them
label: ANALYSIS

text: The plaintiff is bound by his documents and cannot retract from its contents
label: ANALYSIS

text: 27 Ex D1 Certificate dated 30 1 2003 issued by the H M of C K C Higher Primary School Mysore in respect of 2nd defendant and Ex D4 issued by the Dy Director of Public Instructions
label: ANALYSIS

text: clearly establish that the plaintiff is the father of the defendants 28
label: ANALYSIS

text: Paternity is a question of fact
label: ANALYSIS

text: The plaintiff is just hanging on to Ex P3 to prove his case
label: ANALYSIS

text: Having disputed his relationship with the defendants the plaintiff till date has not come forward to undergo DNA test
label: ANALYSIS

text: Further the circumstances under which Ex P3 has come into existence being doubtful I am of the considered view that no relationship can be placed upon Ex P3 29
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Trial court by considering all the probabilities and after careful evaluation of the evidence on record has come to the right just and proper conclusion that the plaintiff is the father of the defendants
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore the point for consideration is answered in the affirmative
label: ANALYSIS

text: 30 Point No 2
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The Learned Counsel for the appellant relies upon the decision in Madhusudan Das Vs Narayani Bai Ors reported in AIR 1983 SC 114 wherein it is held that In an appeal against a Trial Court decree when the appellate court considers an issue turning on oral evidence it must bear in mind that it does not enjoy the advantage which the trial court had in having the witnesses before it and of observing the manner in which they gave their testimony
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: When there is a conflict of oral evidence on any matter in issue and its resolution turns upon the credibility of the witnesses the general rule is that the appellate court should permit the findings of fact rendered by the trial court to prevail unless it clearly appears that some special feature about the evidence of a particular witness has escaped the notice of the trial court or there is a sufficient balance of improbability to displace its opinion as to where the credibility lies
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: This decision in my view is more helpful to the respondent rather than the appellant and therefore it is not applicable to the appellant s case
label: ANALYSIS

text: 31 The decision in Bishwanath Rai Vs Sachhidanand Singh reported in AIR 1971 SC 1949 and Murarilal Vs State of M P reported in AIR 1980 SC 531 are in respect of section 101 and 45 46 373 114 of the Evidence Act
label: PRE_NOT_RELIED

text: These decisions are also not of any help to the appellant as this court is not after proof of authorship of Ex P3 but only the circumstances under which it has come to existence and its genuineness
label: PRE_NOT_RELIED

text: Similarly the decision in Mobarik Ali Ahmed Vs The state of Bombay reported in AIR 1957 SC 857 is also not applicable to the facts of this case
label: PRE_NOT_RELIED

text: 32 For the fore going reasons I am of the considered view that the findings given by the Trial Court in the impugned judgment and decree is well founded and the same does not call for any interference
label: RATIO

text: Accordingly point for consideration is answered in the negative
label: RATIO

text: 33 Point No 3 In the result I pass the following ORDER
label: RPC

text: The Regular appeal filed under order 41 rule 1 of CPC is hereby rejected with cost of Rs 1000
label: RPC

text: The plaintiff has filed this suit against the defendants for the relief of ejectment directing the defendants to hand over vacant possession of the suit schedule property recovery of arrears of rent of Rs 4 29 900 and damages for illegal occupation 2
label: FAC

text: The case of the plaintiff in brief are as follows
label: FAC

text: The plaintiff has contended that the defendant is the tenant of the suit schedule property under late Dr Ahmedulla Khan s o late Dr Ahamed Hussain Khan who had given GPA to his brother Mohammed Jamal Khan to look after the schedule premises
label: FAC

text: On 1 8 1995 the defendant agreed to pay rent at Rs 2282 with increase of rent at 15 once in three years and paying rents to the GPA holder Mohammed Jamal Khan as and when becomes due the same has been made in writing on 1 9 1996
label: FAC

text: After death of Jamal Khan on 8th December 1996 rent was being paid to his son in law Dr Syed Zakiuddin Ali from January 1997 to May 2000 by the defendant and receipts were issued
label: FAC

text: Thereafter defendant has stopped paying rents to Dr Ahmedulla Khan or Dr Syed Zakiuddin Ali
label: FAC

text: Defendant has been informed about the death of Dr Ahmedulla Khan who died in May 2005
label: FAC

text: Legal representatives of said late Dr Ahmedulla Khan have divided the properties through registered partition deed dt 5 4 2006 and the schedule property has fallen to the share of the plaintiffs
label: FAC

text: This fact is also made known to thed by providing khata of the property in their name in September 2008 and plaintiffs have demanded rents due from the defendant but the defendant has not chosen to pay the arrears of rent to the plaintiffs
label: FAC

text: Plaintiffs issued legal notice to the defendant stating that the schedule premises is required for the use of the plaintiffs reasonably and they have terminated the tenancy of the defendant ending on 31st October 2009 and requested the defendant to vacate and hand over the schedule premises and also demanded the arrears of rent
label: FAC

text: The defendant sent an untenable reply but admitted that he is due rent from June 2000 to the owner of the schedule property further contended that late Dr Ahmedulla Khan had no issues
label: FAC

text: Hence this suit
label: FAC

text: 3 After registration of the suit summons was issued to the defendant
label: FAC

text: The defendant appeared through his counsel and filed written statement contending that the suit is not maintainable either in law or on facts
label: FAC

text: He admitted that he is tenant under late Dr Ahmedulla Khan
label: FAC

text: He contended that plaintiffs have no right to claim any arrears of rent as they are strangers to the property in question
label: FAC

text: He admitted that he is tenant under late Dr Ahmedulla Khan under the registered Lease deed dt 27 9 1984 and lease period was for 58 months from 1st October 1984 and initially rate of rent is Rs 1 500 p m
label: FAC

text: He admitted that GPA holder of late Dr Ahmedulla Khan Mohammed Jamal Khan used to collect the rent and defendant enhanced rent to lRs 3 000 p m which was collected till May 2000
label: FAC

text: Thereafter said GPA holder did not turn up though defendant intended to pay rent
label: FAC

text: Said late Dr Ahmedulla Khan had no heirs at law nor legal representatives to succeed to his estate
label: FAC

text: Without seeking the relief of declaration of title considering the prayer of the plaintiffs does not arise
label: FAC

text: Defendant remitted a sum of Rs 42 262 towards assessment payable
label: FAC

text: Plaintiffs have no enforceable rights in relation to the suit schedule property
label: FAC

text: Defendant has never recognised the plaintiffs as his landlords
label: FAC

text: Hence prayed for dismissal of the suit
label: FAC

text: 4 On the basis of the above pleadings this court has framed the following I S S U E S 1
label: ISSUE

text: Whether the plaintiffs prove that they are the absolute owner of the suit schedule
label: ISSUE

text: 2 Whether the plaintiffs prove that the defendant is a tenant under him
label: ISSUE

text: 3 Whether the plaintiffs prove that he has terminated the tenancy by issuing legal notice
label: ISSUE

text: 4 Whether the plaintiffs prove that defendant is liable to pay arrears of rent for a sum of Rs 4 29 900
label: ISSUE

text: 5 Whether the plaintiffs are entitled for the vacant possession of the suit schedule property with damages as prayed in the suit
label: ISSUE

text: 6 What Order or Decree
label: ISSUE

text: 5 The plaintiffs in order to prove their case got examined plaintiff No 6 and GPA holder of other plaintiffs as PW 1 and got marked the documents Ex P 1 to Ex P 22
label: FAC

text: On the other hand the defendant himself examined as Dw 1 and got marked the documents Ex D 1 to Ex D 21
label: FAC

text: 6 Heard the arguments and perused the material on record
label: NONE

text: 7 My findings on the Issues are as under Issue No 1 In the affirmative
label: ANALYSIS

text: Issue No 2 In the affirmative
label: ANALYSIS

text: Issue No 3 In the affirmative
label: ANALYSIS

text: Issue No 4 In the negative
label: ANALYSIS

text: Issue No 5 Partly in the affirmative
label: ANALYSIS

text: Issue No 6 As per the final order for the following R E A S O N S 8 ISSUE NOs 1 2 Since these Issues are interconnected with each other they are taken up togethr in order to avoid repetition of discussion
label: NONE

text: 9 The above pleadings show that there is an assertion from the side of the plaintiffs that the defendant is the tenant under late Dr Ahamedulla Khan and after his death his legal representatives have divided the property through registered Partition deed dt 5 4 2006
label: ANALYSIS

text: This fact was made known to the defendant and the plaintiffs have demanded the rent due to them but the defendant has not chosen to pay arrears of rent to the plaintiffs
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence the plaintiffs are constrained to issue legal notice dt 31 10 2009
label: ANALYSIS

text: The case of the defendant is that there is no relationship of landlord and tenant between himself and the plaintiffs
label: ANALYSIS

text: The original landlord Dr Ahamedulla Khan died and he had had no Issues
label: ANALYSIS

text: Plaintiffs are not the legal representatives of late Dr Ahamedulla Khan
label: ANALYSIS

text: The very title of the plaintiffs is disputed
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence the suit for eviction is not maintainable without seeking the relief of declaration
label: ANALYSIS

text: 10 In this regard both the parties have let their evidence
label: ANALYSIS

text: That Pw 1 has reiterated the averments made in the plaint in his examination in chief affidavit and marked the original GPA executed by the other plaintiffs in her favour as Ex P 1 to Ex P 5
label: ANALYSIS

text: She also got marked the certified copy of the registered Partition deed dt 5 4 2006 executed between the plaintiffs and other legal representatives of late Dr Ahamedulla Khan at Ex P 6
label: ANALYSIS

text: Other suit schedule property documents are marked at Ex P 7 Ex P 8 Rent Receipts as per Ex P 9 P 10 GPA executed by Dr Ahamedulla Khan in favour of the Mohammed JamalKhan who is father of plaintiffs as per Ex P 11 Lease Agreement as per Ex P 12 Authorisation letter to the defendant to pay rent issued by her uncle in favour of her father as per Ex P 13 Title deed dt 31 8 1994 issued by Mysore Urban Development Authority to late Dr Ahamedulla Khan as Ex P 14 Ex P 15 is Genealogical tree Ex P 16 is Family survival members certificate Declarations made by Obedulla Khan Dr Rahamth Ulla Khan and Taj Unnissa as Ex P 17 to Ex P 19 Death certificates of Mohammed Jamal Khan Dr Ahmed Ulla Khan andDr Zameela Begum Nayira as Ex P 20 to Ex P 22
label: ANALYSIS

text: 11 An attempt was made to elicit something in the cross examination of Pw 1 but she successfully withstood the test of cross examination
label: ANALYSIS

text: Though Dw 1 has reiterated the written statement averments in his examination in chief but in the cross examination the learned Counsel for the plaintiffs has elicited some important admissions and the same will be discussed at a later point of time
label: ANALYSIS

text: 12 Dw 1 got marked the cheque book as Ex D 1 16 rent paid receipts as Ex D 2 to Ex D 17 Notice dt 30 11 2004issued by the Mysore City Corporation as Ex D 18 Tax paid receipt dt 10 1 2005 as Ex D 19 Accounts extract of the defendant as Ex D 20 Paper publication dt 11 12 2004 in Vijaya Karnataka daily newspaper as Ex D 21 and Ex D 21 a
label: ANALYSIS

text: 13 The learned Counsel for the plaintiffs has argued that the suit schedule property fallen to the share of the plaintiffs through registered Partition deed dt 5 4 2006
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: After coming to know of this fact also the defendant did not pay arrears of rent
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Hence the tenancy was duly terminated on 31 10 2009
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 14 Per contra the learned Counsel for the defendant has filed written arguments admitting the jural relationship between him and late Dr Ahamedulla Khan
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: He further contended that he demise of late Dr Ahamedulla Khan during May 2005 was informed to the defendant is disputed and registered partition deed is not a sustainable document
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: There was no heirs to Dr Ahamedulla Khan
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: The allegation of the plaintiffs that the property came to be recorded in the names of the plaintiffs is also disputed by the defendant
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Plaintiffs have no right to claim any arrears as they are strangers
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: As there is no relationship of landlord and tenant between himself and the plaintiffs the suit of the plaintiffs is not maintainable
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Without considering the right of the plaintiffs in the absence of any suit and decree from the competent Court of law plaintiffs are not entitled to any of the reliefs
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: From these construction of the parties and documents the fact remains is that whether the tenant can deny title of the landlord
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: 15 With these contentions taken up by the parties I have perused the pleadings evidence and other materials on record
label: ANALYSIS

text: Plaintiffs have contended that the suit schedule property fallen to their share through registered partition deed dt 5 4 2006
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is the case of the plaintiffs that late Dr Ahamedulla Khan is the landlord and defendant is the tenant under the plaintiff
label: ANALYSIS

text: Dr Ahamedulla Khan had given GPA to his brother Mohammed Jamal Khan in respect of the the suit schedule property and the defendant agreed to pay rent at the rate of Rs 2282 with an increase of rent at 15 once in three years
label: ANALYSIS

text: Accordingly defendant was paying rent to the GPA holder Mohammed Jamal Khan
label: ANALYSIS

text: The claim is not disputed by the defendant
label: ANALYSIS

text: After the demise of Mohammed Jamal Khan the rent was being paid to his son in law Syed Zakiuddin Ali from January 1997to June 2000 by the defendant and receipts were issued
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thereafter defendant stopped paying the rent
label: ANALYSIS

text: Said Dr Ahamedulla Khan died during May 2005
label: ANALYSIS

text: The legal representatives of the deceased Dr Ahmedulla Khan have divided the properties of late Dr Ahamedulla Khan through registered partition deed dt 5 4 2006 and the suit schedule property has fallen to the share of the plaintiffs who are the sons and daughters of Mohammed Jamal Khan who was the brother of late Dr Ahamedulla Khan
label: ANALYSIS

text: In this case the defendant has not disputed the landlord and tenant relationship between himself and the deceased Dr Ahmadulla Khan
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is the only defence of the defendant that the plaintiffs are not the legal representatives of the deceased Dr Ahmadulla Khan
label: ANALYSIS

text: The defendant himself in his cross examination has admitted that the deceased Dr Ahmadulla Khan has no issue
label: ANALYSIS

text: At Ex P 6 which is the registered Partition deed the defendants and other legal representatives of Dr Ahmadulla Khan have stated that the wife of the said Dr Ahmadulla Khan has taken a voluntary divorce long back
label: ANALYSIS

text: Further defendants have produced the genealogical tree which is marked at Ex P 15 shows that plaintiffs are also legal heirs of the deceased Dr Ahmadulla Khan
label: ANALYSIS

text: The other legal representatives of Dr Ahmadulla Khan have also filed declaration at Ex P 17 to Ex P 19 stating that the suit schedule property originally belongs to their brother Dr Ahmadulla Khan and he died leaving behind him the defendants and themselves as his legal heirs
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex P 6 which is the registered Partition deed clearly shows that the plaintiffs and other legal heirs of the deceased Dr Ahmadulla Khan have divided the properties of Dr Ahmadulla Khan and the suit schedule property fallen to the share of the plaintiffs
label: ANALYSIS

text: 16 It is further defence of the defendant that he has disputed the title of the plaintiffs over the suit schedule propert hence the suit for eviction without seeking the relief of declaration is not maintainable
label: ANALYSIS

text: 17 Where a tenant with full knowledge of the fats either expressly or in writing or impliedly by acts such as the payment of rent attorns tenant to a person other than his original landlord or one who is claiming the estate of interest of such original landlord by assignment succession or othewise he is ordinarily estopped from questioning the title of the person to whom he has so attorned
label: ANALYSIS

text: Under Section 116 of the Indian Evidence Act the tenant is estopped from questioning the title of the landlord
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence the defendant is precluded from question title of the landlord on the general principles of estoppel between landlord and tenant
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence the defence of the defendant is not maintainable
label: ANALYSIS

text: 18 The defendant in his cross examination has admitted that he stopped paying rent from June 2000
label: ANALYSIS

text: Admittedly the original landlord Dr Ahmedulla Khan died in the year 2005
label: ANALYSIS

text: But the defendant has not put forward his steps to deposit the rent before the Court and to pay the rent to Dr Ahmedulla Khan
label: ANALYSIS

text: The very act of the defendant itself shows that he is making false claim
label: ANALYSIS

text: The acts of the plaintiffs by adducing oral and documentary evidence have established their case that they are the absolute owners of the suit schedule property by virtue of Partition deed dt 5 4 2006 and defendant is tenant under them
label: ANALYSIS

text: Accordingly I answer Issue Nos 1 2 in the affirmative
label: ANALYSIS

text: 19 ISSUE NO 3
label: ANALYSIS

text: This Issue is framed with respect to termination of tenancy by issuing legal notice
label: ANALYSIS

text: Plaintiffs have asserted that the notice dt 16 10 2009 issued to the defendant terminating the tenancy on 31 10 2009 is valid under law
label: ANALYSIS

text: Of course there is no dispute with regard to issuance of such notice in favour of the defendant and the defendant has given reply to the said notice
label: ANALYSIS

text: While answering Issues 1 2 have concluded that the plaintiffs are the absolute owners of the suit schedule property and defendant is tenant under them
label: ANALYSIS

text: Said notice was issued on 16 9 2009 which is marked at Ex P 24 which was served on the defendant on 22 9 2009
label: ANALYSIS

text: The acknowledgement for the same is marked as Ex P 25 and the defendant has also issued reply dt 15 10 2009 as per Ex P 26
label: ANALYSIS

text: The plaintiff has called upon the defendant to vacate the deliver vacant possession by the end of tenancy month 31 10 2009
label: ANALYSIS

text: The plaintiff in the notice has clearly stated that the tenancy was terminated by the end of 31 10 2009
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thereafter plaintiffs have waited for more than 15 days to file this suit
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore the said notice is in consolance with the provisions of S 106 of the Transfer of Property Act
label: ANALYSIS

text: Accordingly I hold that the notice dt 16 09 2009 is valid under law and I answer Issue No 3 in the affirmative
label: ANALYSIS

text: 20 ISSUE NO 4
label: ANALYSIS

text: This Issue is framed with respect to arrears of rent of Rs 4 29 900 by the defendant
label: ANALYSIS

text: Though the defendant admitted that he stopped paying rent from June 2000 it is not the case of the plaintiffs that they have issued attornment notice to the defendant after property fallen to their share under the Partition deed dt 5 4 2006
label: ANALYSIS

text: Plaintiffs have further contended that they have informed the defendant during September 2008 that they have acquired the property in their name but no document is produced by the plaintiffs to show that they have issued attornment notice to the defendant
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence in my opinion the plaintiffs are not entitled for the arrears of rent till the tenancy is terminated
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore I hold that the defendant is liable to pay arrears of rent only from the date of termination of tenancy
label: ANALYSIS

text: Accordingly Issue 4 is answered in the negative
label: ANALYSIS

text: 21 ISSUE NO 5
label: ANALYSIS

text: This Issue is framed with respect to entitlement of the plaintiffs for vacant possession of the suit schedule property from the defendant with damages
label: ANALYSIS

text: While answering Issues 1 2 I have concluded that plaintiffs are the absolute owners of the suit schedule property and defendant is tenant under them
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence the plaintiffs are entitled for vacant possession of the suit schedule property
label: RATIO

text: Plaintiffs have also claimed damages from the date of termination of tenancy as defendant is in unauthorised occupation of the suit schedule property
label: RATIO

text: The remedy of the plaintiffs is to seek damages or mesne profits from the date of termination till possession
label: RATIO

text: At present there is no evidence to ascertain the damages
label: RATIO

text: Hence Court shall order to make a separate enquiry to ascertain the damages
label: RATIO

text: Accordingly Issue 5 is answered partly in the affirmative
label: RATIO

text: 22 ISSUE NO 6
label: RPC

text: In view of above discussion and conclusion arrive at Issues 1 to 5 I proceed to pass the following O R D E R
label: RPC

text: The suit of the plaintiffs is partly decreed
label: RPC

text: The defendant is hereby directed to vacate and hand over vacant possession of the suit schedule property to the plaintiffs within three months from the date of this judgment
label: RPC

text: The suit of the plaintiffs for recovery of arrears of rent is hereby dismissed
label: RPC

text: There shall be a separate enquiry under Or 20 Rule 12 of C P C to ascertain damages or mesne profits
label: RPC

text: Parties to bear their own costs
label: RPC

text: Draw decree accordingly
label: RPC

text: PETITIONER KHANDU SONU DHOBI AND ANR Vs RESPONDENT STATE OF MAHARASHTRA DATE OF JUDGMENT15 02 1972 BENCH
label: PREAMBLE

text: KHANNA HANS RAJ
label: PREAMBLE

text: BENCH KHANNA HANS RAJ SHELAT J M REDDY P JAGANMOHAN CITATION 1972 AIR 958 1972 SCR 3 510 1972 SCC 3 786 14 35 CITATOR INFO 125 R 1973 SC 913 R 1974 SC 923 RF 1992 SC 604 ACT Penal Code 1860 45 of 1860 S 403 Dishonest misappropriation for a time only is misappropriation
label: PREAMBLE

text: Prevention
label: PREAMBLE

text: of Corruption Act 2 of 1947 S
label: PREAMBLE

text: 5A Investigation conducted in breach of section Illegality must result in miscarriage of justice
label: PREAMBLE

text: Bombay Land Improvement Schemes Act 1942 Sub section 1 and 2 of s 23 Bar of prosecution applies only to any thing done in good faith or under the Act
label: PREAMBLE

text: HEADNOTE
label: PREAMBLE

text: The appellants entrusted with the duties of carrying out improvement schemes under the Bombay Land Improvement Scheme Act 1942 were charged with the offence of preparing false documents and committing criminal breach of trust in respect of certain amount
label: PREAMBLE

text: It was alleged that even though no work had been done and no amount had been disbursed they prepared documents showing the doing of the work and payment of the amount They were convicted under s 218 read with section 34 section 477A read with section 34 and section 409 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code as well as section 5 2
label: PREAMBLE

text: read with section 5 1 d of the Prevention of Corruption Act
label: PREAMBLE

text: The High Court affirmed the conviction
label: PREAMBLE

text: in the appeal to this Court it was contended that after the matter had been reported to the higher authorities the rectification work was done and the money was disbursed for the purpose for which it had been entrusted that the conviction was bad because of non compliance with section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act and that the prosecution was barred by time under s 23 of the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes Act 1942 Dismissing the appeal
label: PREAMBLE

text: HELD i There is no cogent ground to disagree with the trial court and the High Court that the accused had prepared
label: PREAMBLE

text: false documents bad also committed criminal breach of trust and were in the discharge of their duties guilty of criminal misconduct as defined in s 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act
label: PREAMBLE

text: ii It is no answer to a charge of criminal misappropriation that after the matter bad been reported to the higher authorities the accused got
label: PREAMBLE

text: the rectification work done or the money was subsequently disbursed for the purpose for which it had been entrusted
label: PREAMBLE

text: According to explanation 1 to section 403 Indian Penal Code
label: PREAMBLE

text: a dishonest misappropriation for a time only is misappropriation within the meaning of that section
label: PREAMBLE

text: iii It is well established that cognizance of a case has in fact been taken by the court on a police report following investigation conducted in breach of provisions of section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act the result of the trial cannot be set aside unless the illegality in theinvestigation can be shown to have brought about a miscarriage of justice
label: PREAMBLE

text: The reason for the above dictum is that an illegality committed during the course of investigation does not effect the competence and jurisdiction of the Court to try the accused
label: PREAMBLE

text: Where therefore the trial of the case has proceeded to termination the invalidity of the preceding investigation would not vitiate the conviction of the accused as a result of the trial unless the illegality in the investigation has caused prejudice to the accused
label: PREAMBLE

text: Since there has been no miscarriage of justice in the present case because of the alleged non compliance with section 5A the conviction of the appellants cannot be set aside on that score
label: PREAMBLE

text: 515 H H N Rishbud and Inder Singh v The State of Delhi 1955 1 S C R 1150 referred to
label: PREAMBLE

text: iv Sub section i of the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes Act 1942 has plainly no application as it relates to anyth ing done in the good faith
label: PREAMBLE

text: It cannot also be said that the acts of the appellants in preparing false documents and committing criminal breach of trust as also the act of criminal misconduct were done under the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes Act within the meaning of sub section 2
label: PREAMBLE

text: The subsection has no application where something is done not under the Act even though it has been done by a public servant who has been entrusted with the duties of carrying improvement schemes under this Act
label: PREAMBLE

text: The impugned acts of the appellants was not in discharge of their duties under the Act but in obvious breach and flagrant disregard of their duties
label: PREAMBLE

text: 516 G 517 D JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No 105 of 1969
label: NONE

text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 27 1969 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos 53 and 45 of 1968
label: NONE

text: V S Kotwal A G Ratnaparkhi and Rajiv Shah for the appellant
label: NONE

text: R M Mehta and B D Sharma for the respondent
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Khanna J
label: NONE

text: This is an appeal by special leave by Khandu Sonu Dhobi and Bhikanrao Rambhau Khairnar against the judgment of the Bombay High Court affirming on appeal the conviction of the appellants under section 218 read with section 34 section 477A read with section 34 and section 409 read with section 34 of Indian Penal Code as well as under section 5 2 read with section 5 1 d of the Prevention of Corruption Act
label: FAC

text: Sentence of rigorous imprisonment for a period of one year and a fine of Rs 200 or in default further rigorous imprisonment for a period of two months has been awarded on each count to the appellants
label: RLC

text: The substantive sentences have ben ordered to run concurrently
label: RLC

text: Dhobi appellant No 1 was an agricultural assistant and was working under Khairnar appellant No 2 who was agriculturalsupervisor in the soil conservation section of the Government of Maharashtra
label: FAC

text: Dhobi was incharge of the work relating to a Bundh in block No 13 of village Asane in Taluka Mandurbar
label: FAC

text: The above block comprises agricultural lands bearing survey Nos 8 17 18 19 and 32 measuring 90 acres
label: FAC

text: The Bundhs were being constructed since the year 1962
label: FAC

text: Rectification work in respect of those Bundhs at a cost of Rs 369 07 had to be got done by Dhobi appellant under the supervision of Khaimar appellant
label: FAC

text: The Government sanctioned an amount of Rs 4779 in connection with the construction of the Bundhs
label: FAC

text: An advance amount of Rs 5000 was received by Khaimar accused on March 2 1966 in that connection
label: FAC

text: Work of the value of Rs 4400 was done but that relating to rectification work was not done
label: FAC

text: According to the rules of the soil conservation section the Government spent the money in the first instance and after the report of the completion of work was received the expenses were recovered from the landowners for whose benefit the work was done
label: FAC

text: On March 11 1966 Khaimar made entries in measurement book Ex 27 showing that he had checked 28 payments and certified the same
label: FAC

text: Khaimar accused also stated in the entry that he had passed the measurements and paid Rs 369 07
label: FAC

text: Paysheets Ex 64 were prepared by Dhobi accused and he obtained the thumb impressions and signatures of the laborers on the paysheets
label: FAC

text: Khaimar made his initials below the thumb impressions in the paysheets
label: FAC

text: On the last page of the paysheets Khaimar signed a certificate according to which he had paid Rs 369 07 to PW 10 Jagan Trinibak who used to do the labour work
label: FAC

text: Final bill Ex 28
label: FAC

text: was also prepared on that day by the accused and the signature of Jagan Trimbak was obtained on the same
label: FAC

text: The bill was got signed from PW 7 Ziparu Tukaram and another person as attesting witnesses
label: FAC

text: The bill was signed thereafter by Khaimar
label: FAC

text: Debit entry Ex 32 of Rs
label: FAC

text: was made by Khaimar accused in the cash book
label: FAC

text: He also prepared work abstract Ex 29 on April 16 1966 and sent it to the sub divisional soil conservation officer Nandurbar showing an expenditure of Rs 369 07
label: FAC

text: The case of the prosecution was that the measurement book Ex 27 paysheets Ex 64 final bill Ex 28 and cash book entry Ex 32 were false documents and were fabricated by the accused without doing any reification work on the Bundh
label: FAC

text: The accused thus committed criminal breach of trust in respect of the amount of Rs 369 07 in furtherance of their common intention to misappropriate government property
label: FAC

text: According further to the prosecution case the landowners in block No 13 came to know of the above acts of the accused and they complained about it to Sarpanch Tanku Bhagwan PW 12
label: FAC

text: Tanku sent a telegram on April 12 1966 to the superintending agricultural officer Bombay division Nasik in this connection
label: FAC

text: A copy of the telegram wasthereafter sent by the superintending agricultural officer to divisional soil conservation officer D S D Ghate PW 1 for necessary action as well as for enquiry and report
label: FAC

text: Chate PW went to village Asane on May 2 1966 and inspected block No 13
label: FAC

text: He found that entries had been made about the payment of Rs 369 07 in the measurement book and cash book even though no rectification work had been done
label: FAC

text: Chate submitted his report on May 6 1966 for proceeding departmentally against the accused
label: FAC

text: On receipt of the above report the superintending agricultural officer directed P R Inamdar PW 1 1 deputy director of agricultural engineering to go to Asane village and submit his report after personally verifying the facts
label: FAC

text: Inamdar went with Ghate to block No 13 in Asane village on May 11 1966
label: FAC

text: Both Inamdar and Ghate found that no rectification work had been done
label: FAC

text: They did not find even a single pit in the lands in that block although according to measurement book 83 pits had been recently dug
label: FAC

text: Inamdar and Ghate also met the Sarpanch and other landowners of Asane village
label: FAC

text: Report dated May 18 1966 was thereafter submitted by Inamdar affirming those facts
label: FAC

text: Sarpanch Tanku sent complaint Ex 84 in the meanwhile on April 30 1966 to the director of anti corruption branch Maharashtra State stating that the accused had prepared false bill for Rs 369 07 without doing any work and that they had misappropriated that amount
label: FAC

text: It was also stated that attempts were being made to shield the accused
label: FAC

text: The director of anti corruption sent a copy of that application to Sub Inspector K G Patil PW 13 who was then attached to Dhulia officse of the anticorruption branch
label: FAC

text: Sub Inspector Patil made local enquiry and took into possession the measurement book paysheets and cash book
label: FAC

text: The director of anti corruption branch directed Patil to register a case and investigate into the matter
label: FAC

text: Patil went to Nasik and recorded statement Ex 79 of Inamdar PW on November 7 1966
label: FAC

text: The statement was then sent to Nandurbar Taluka police station
label: FAC

text: A case was registered on the basis of that statement at the police station on November 8 1966
label: FAC

text: On November 12 1966 sub Inspector Patil applied for permission under section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act of judicial magistrate 1st class to investigate the offence
label: FAC

text: The permission was granted by the judicial magistrate 1st class Nandurbar on the same day
label: FAC

text: Patil thereafter recorded statements of a number of persons
label: FAC

text: Patil was subsequently transferred and the case was investigated by his successors Mahamuni and Kulkarni who also obtained the requisite permission
label: FAC

text: Sanction Ex 97 for the prosecution of the two accused was granted under section 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act by the superintending agricultural officer Bombay division Nasik on May 18 1967 The
label: FAC

text: two accused in their statements admitted that the work of the value of Rs 369 07 wasnot done till March 11 1966 although it was so stated in the various documents by them
label: FAC

text: The accused also admitted that no amounts were paid to any of the labourers mentioned in the paysheets although signatures and thumb impressions of the labourers had been obtained on the paysheets on March 11 1966
label: FAC
