text: According to the accused they had prepared the various documents in accordance with the instructions of Ghate PW who was insisting in March 1966 and even earlier that a completion report relating to block No 13 be sent as the entire amount spent on that block since 1962 could not be recovered for want of a completion report
label: FAC

text: Khaimar accused added that rectification work had been done between May 13 1966 and May 16 1966 and the amount of Rs 369 07 was thereafter disbursed on May 16 1966
label: FAC

text: The learned special judge held that the amount of Rs 369 07 had not been paid by the two accused to the labourers
label: RLC

text: No work it was found had been done and the different documents prepared by the accused in this connection were false even on their own admissions
label: RLC

text: The explanation furnished by the accused that they prepared false documents at the instance of Ghate and got work done thereafter was not accepted
label: RLC

text: Objection was raised on behalf of the accused that the investigation of the case was illegal and that prosecution was barred by time under the pro visions of section 23 of the Land Improvement Schemes Act 1942
label: FAC

text: These objections were repelled
label: FAC

text: The accused were accordingly convicted and sentenced as above
label: FAC

text: On appeal the High Court affirmed the findings of the learned special judge
label: FAC

text: We have heard Mr Kotwal on behalf of the appellants and are of the opinion that there is no merit in the appeal
label: ANALYSIS

text: It has not been disrupted before us that the accused made various entries and prepared documents on March 11 1966 about their having got the rectification work done as well as about the payment of Rs 369 07 on that account
label: ANALYSIS

text: It has also not been disputed before us that the amount of Rs 369 07 was not paid to any one by the accused in March or April 1966
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to Ghate PW 1 and Inamdar PW 11 no work relating to the rectification of the Bundh was found to have been done till May 11 1966 when they visited the site in question
label: ANALYSIS

text: Inamdar s evidence also shows that according to the measurement book prepared by the accused 83 pits had been recently dug although the witness could not find a single pit on the spot
label: ANALYSIS

text: In view of the above we find no cogent ground to disagree with the trial court and the High Court that the accused had prepared false documents and had also committed criminal breach of trust in respectof the amount of Rs 369 07
label: ANALYSIS

text: We also agree with the trial court and the High Court that the accused were in the discharge of their duties guilty of criminal misconduct as defined in section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act
label: ANALYSIS

text: Mr Kotwal has argued that the accused completed the recti fication work after May 11 1966
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is however no direct evidence as may show that the rectification work was completed after May 11 1966
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even if it may be assumed that the accused completed the rectification work in May 1966 that fact in our opinion would not absolve the accused of their criminal liability
label: ANALYSIS

text: The charge against the accused relates to preparation of false documents because even though no work had been done till March 11 1966 and no amount had been disbursed they prepared docu ments showing the doing of that work and the payment of that amount
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is no answer to that charge that after the matter had been reported to the higher authorities the accused in the month of May 1966 got the rectification work done
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is also no answer to a charge of criminal misappropriation that the money was subsequently after the matter had been reported to the high authorities disbursed for the purpose for which it had been entrusted
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to explanation 1 to section 403 Indian Penal Code a dishonest misappropriation for a time only is misappropriation within the meaning of that section
label: ANALYSIS

text: Mr Kotwal has also submitted that the accused expressed willingness to complete the work after the matter had been reported to the higher authorities
label: ANALYSIS

text: This submission even if accepted would not exonerate the accused because the willingness after the matter had been reported to the higher authorities could not efface or undo the offence earlier committed by the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: Argument has then been advanced on behalf of the appellants that Sub Inspector Patil did not make investigation in the case in accordance with law
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is urged that permission to make investigation was granted to Sub Inspector Patil on November 12 1966 and as such he was not authorized to make before that date the enquiry which led to the registration of the case as that enquiry partook of the character of investigation
label: ANALYSIS

text: Nothing has been brought to our notice as to how an enquiry before the registration of a case can be held to be investigation
label: ANALYSIS

text: The matter however need not be dilated upon and it is not necessary to express any final opinion in the matter because we find that there is no material on the record as may show that the accused were prejudiced because of the alleged non compliance with the provisions of section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is well established that where cxognizance of a case has in fact been taken by the court on a police report following investigationconducted in breach of provisions of section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act the result of the trial cannot be set aside unless the illegality in the investigation can be shown to have brought about a miscarriage of justice
label: ANALYSIS

text: The underlying reason for the above dictum is that an illegality committed in the course of investigation does not affect the competence and jurisdiction of the court to try the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: Where therefore the trial of the case has proceeded to termination the invalidity of the proceeding investigation would not vitiate the conviction of the accused as a result of the trial unless the illegality in the investigation has caused prejudice to the accused see H N Rishbud and Inder Singh v The State of DelHi 1
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Since there has been no miscarriage of justice in the present case because of the alleged non compliance with section 5A the conviction of the accused appellants cannot be set aside on that score
label: ANALYSIS

text: For the same reason we are unable to accede to the contention of Mr Kotwal that the conviction of the accused should be set aside because permission under section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act to SI Patil for investigation of the offence was granted in a casual manner and without the existence of sufficient reasons
label: ANALYSIS

text: Lastly it has been argued by Mr Kotwal that the prosecution of the accused was barred by time under section 23 of the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes Act 1942
label: ANALYSIS

text: The section reads as under 1 No suit prosecution or other legal proceeding shall be instituted against any public servant or person duly authorized under this Act in respect of anything in good faith done or intended to be done under this Act or the rules made thereunder 2 No suit or prosecution shall be instituted against any public servant or person duly authorized under this Act in respect of anything done or intended to be done under this Act unless the suit or prosecution has been instituted within six months from the date of the act complained of Sub section 1 of the section has plainly no application as it relates to anything done in good faith
label: STA

text: According to Bombay General Clauses Act a thing shall be deemed to be done in good faith where it is in fact done honestly whether it is done negligently or not
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellants admittedly were not acting honestly when they prepared the false documents in question and showed disbursement of Rs 369 07 on March 11 1966
label: ANALYSIS

text: Mr Kotwal however relies on sub section 2 of section 23 and 1 1955 1 S C R 1150 submits that the prosecution could be instituted against the appellants only within six months from March 11 1966
label: ANALYSIS

text: As the charge sheet was submitted long after the expire of six months the case against the accused appellants according to the counsel was barred by time
label: ANALYSIS

text: This contention in our opinion is devoid of force
label: ANALYSIS

text: Sub section 2 refers to suit or prosecution against a public servant or person duly authorized under the Act in respect of anything done or intended to be done under the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes Act
label: ANALYSIS

text: It cannot be said that the acts of the accused appellants in preparing false documents and in committing criminal breach of trust in respect of the amount of Rs 369 07 as also their act of criminal misconduct were done under the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes Act
label: ANALYSIS

text: Sub section 2 of section 23 deals with anything done or intended to be done under the above mentioned Act by a public servant or a person duly authorized under the Act
label: ANALYSIS

text: It has no application where something is done not under the Act even though it has been done by a public servant who has been entrusted with duties of carrying out improvement schemes under the above mentioned Act
label: ANALYSIS

text: The impugned acts of the appellants in the present case were not in discharge of their duties under the above mentioned Act but in obvious breach and flagrant disregard of their duties
label: RATIO

text: Not only they did no rectification work for the Bundh which was a part of the improvement scheme they also misappropriated the amount which had been entrusted to them for the purpose of rectification
label: RATIO

text: Prayer has also been made for the reduction of the sentence but we see no cogent ground to interfere with the same
label: RPC

text: The appeal consequently fails and is dismissed
label: RPC

text: K B N Appeal dismissed 5 L1031 Sup CI 72
label: NONE

text: REPORTABLE IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA
label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CRIMINAL APPEAL NO 1893 OF 2010 GURU GURUBARAN ORS APPELLANT S
label: PREAMBLE

text: Versus
label: PREAMBLE

text: STATE REP BY INSP OF POLICE RESPONDENT S J U D G M E N T
label: PREAMBLE

text: Deepak Gupta J 1
label: NONE

text: This appeal is filed by Accused Nos 1 2 3 5 and 9 against the judgment of the High Court whereby Guru Gurubaran A1 and Durai Durairajan A2 have been convicted under Section 302 Indian Penal Code IPC and sentenced to imprisonment for life and to pay a fine of Rs 1000 each with default sentence of 3 months rigorous imprisonment RI
label: RLC

text: As far as Vettri Vetrivell A3 is concerned
label: RLC

text: he was convicted under Section 324 IPC on two counts and sentenced to one year RI on each count and fine of Rs 1000 with default sentence of 3 months
label: RLC

text: Narayanan A5 and Srinivasan A9 along with other accused were convicted under Section 323 IPC and sentenced to undergo six months RI and pay fine of Rs 1000 each with default sentence of 3 months
label: RLC

text: All the sentences were to run concurrently
label: RLC

text: 2 The prosecution case is that Parasuraman PW14 son of deceased Saroja and Munusamy Pillai PW1 was in love with Uma the younger sister of A1
label: FAC

text: They both got married and after the marriage PW14 lived in his wife s house
label: FAC

text: However Saroja deceased did not approve of this
label: FAC

text: Thereafter PW14 came back to his house
label: FAC

text: On 03 03 1998 it is alleged that Jayaraman A4 assaulted Nagarajan PW2 brother of Saroja and brotherinlaw of PW1
label: FAC

text: To settle the dispute a Panchayat was called the next day
label: FAC

text: It is admitted that this Panchayat was called at the instance of A1
label: FAC

text: The Panchayat was to be conducted in the evening
label: FAC

text: However since the Pradhan of the Panchayat was indisposed the Panchayat could not be held
label: FAC

text: Thereafter PW2 his sister Saroja deceased his wife Rani PW7 Murugan PW13 and Naveen Kumar son of PW2 and PW7 stood outside the house of PW2 talking amongst themselves
label: FAC

text: According to him PW13 had come to the village because of the Panchayat
label: FAC

text: While they were standing there A1 came armed with a sickle Koduval A2 armed with an Iron Pipe A3 armed with a sickle Koduval and A4 to A9 carrying thick wooden staffs in their hands
label: FAC

text: It is alleged that A1 attacked deceased Saroja with a sickle on the front portion of her head and said that it was only because of her that the younger sister of A1 has to live separately from her husband
label: FAC

text: A2 gave a blow on the back of the neck of Saroja with an iron pipe
label: FAC

text: The other accused are alleged to have attacked Saroja with wooden staffs in their hand
label: FAC

text: When the family members of Saroja tried to protect her all the 9 accused surrounded her and as such they could not protect her
label: FAC

text: According to the eyewitnesses they were also attacked by the members of the aggressive party
label: FAC

text: The version of all the eye witnesses is similar
label: FAC

text: 3 However there are some discrepancies with regard to the manner in which the said incident took place
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to PW 1 on the date of Panchayat first a verbal altercation took place between the two sides and then the attack took place whereas according to PW2 and some of the other eyewitnesses the attack took place without any provocation
label: FAC

text: We are of the considered view that for the purpose of deciding this appeal we can even presume that there was some verbal altercation between the two sides
label: ANALYSIS

text: 4 The occurrence is not denied
label: ANALYSIS

text: The main defence is that there was a free fight on both sides and that there is no evidence to show that there is prior meeting of minds
label: ANALYSIS

text: The accused had not been convicted under Section 34 or Section 149 IPC and therefore each individual accused can only be convicted for the injury attributed to that individual
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore it becomes relevant to refer to the medical evidence of the autopsy surgeon Dr Rajamani Assistant Surgeon PW3
label: FAC

text: The injuries are as follows 1 An Antemortem red oblique lacerated wound measuring 6cm x 1cm x 1cm exposing the bones over the left frontal region of scalp 1 cm away from the midline with bleeding and blood clots
label: FAC

text: On Exploring the wound echymosis seen behind the scalp over the frontal parietal temporal and back of skull
label: FAC

text: There is a fracture of frontal bone measuring 5 cm in length vertical para sagittally and 1cm away from midline over the left side extended to upwards to fronto parietal junction and another fracture line which is adjacent to it and slightly oblique from the frontal bone to towards fronto parietal junction 4cm x 1 8 on and on exposing the skull bones blood clots seen over the membranes of the leftcerebral hemisphere of brain on the frontal parietal temporal and occipital region of the brain
label: FAC

text: Both fractures are involving inner and outer table of the skull
label: FAC

text: 2 An abrasions varying size from 3cm to 21 2cm x cm with cm different from each other oblique placed over middle 1 3 of right side neck
label: FAC

text: 3 An AM abrasion 21 2cm x cm obliquely placed 1cm away from injury No 2 on right side of neck
label: FAC

text: 4 An AM swelling whole of the anterior and lateral side of right side neck
label: FAC

text: On exposing the injury No 2 3 4 minor blood clots under the skin of neck and congestion of sternomastoid muscle and blood clots seen in anterior and lateral side of right side neck
label: FAC

text: 5 The doctor states that these injuries caused the death
label: FAC

text: The first injury is a lacerated wound and it is urged by Mr S Nagamuthu learned senior counsel that this injury could not have been caused by sickle Koduval which is a sharpedged weapon
label: FAC

text: A sickle is an instrument mainly meant for cutting grass and crops
label: FAC

text: The inner side is sharp but the outer side is blunt
label: FAC

text: While using it as an instrument of agriculture only the sharp edge is used but while using it as a weapon of offence more often than not it will be the outer side which will be used to hit the victim
label: FAC

text: The doctor has opined that the injury could have been caused by a sickle which is MO1 and therefore the medical evidence fully corroborates the version of all the eye witnesses
label: FAC

text: 6 It was next urged that the offence was not of murder but may amount to culpable homicide not amounting to murder
label: FAC

text: It has been urged that the case would fall within Exception 4 to Section 300 IPC which reads as follows Exception 4 Culpable homicide is not murder if it is committed without premeditation in a sudden fight in the heat of passion upon a sudden quarrel and without the offender having taken undue advantage or acted in a cruel or unusual manner 7
label: STA

text: We are of the view that the accused cannot take benefit of this Exception
label: ANALYSIS

text: It has come in evidence that all the accused persons came armed
label: ANALYSIS

text: Two were armed with sickles one with an iron pipe and the other with wooden staffs
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even if it is assumed that they may not have come with the intention of killing the fact that they were armed clearly indicates that the occurrence did not take place in the heat of passion upon a sudden quarrel
label: ANALYSIS

text: As pointed out above both sides were coming to attend a Panchayat to settle a dispute
label: ANALYSIS

text: Where was the need to carry arms if the intention was only to settle a dispute
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even otherwise we feel that Exception 4 is not applicable because the manner in which the blow was given right on the middle of the head brings this case squarely within clause Fourthly of Section 300 IPC which reads as follows 300 Murder xxx xxx xxx Secondly xxx xxx xxx Thirdly xxx xxx xxx Fourthly If the person committing the act knows that it is so imminently dangerous that it must in all probability cause death or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death and commits such act without any excuse for incurring the risk of causing death or such injury as aforesaid
label: STA

text: 8 A1 should have known that the act which he is performing of hitting the deceased on the head with a sickle with such great force causing fracture of the skull is so dangerous that it would have imminently caused death
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore we find no reason to alter the sentence or conviction of Guru Gurubaran A1
label: RATIO

text: 9 However as far as Durai Durairajan A2 is concerned since the High Court has held that neither Section 34 nor Section 149 IPC are applicable each accused will only be responsible for his own acts and injuries
label: RATIO

text: In this behalf reference was made to a judgment of this Court in the case of Atmaram Zingaraji vs State of Maharashtra1
label: RATIO

text: There is no appeal by the State
label: RATIO

text: As far as A2 is concerned he is alleged to have given a blow with an iron pipe on the back of the neck of the deceased
label: RATIO

text: This resulted in injury numbers 2 and 3
label: RATIO

text: They are merely abrasions and could not have caused death
label: RATIO

text: Therefore the accused can only be held guilty of having committed the offence under Section 324 IPC
label: RATIO

text: He has already undergone imprisonment for around 11 years and therefore his conviction under Section 302 IPC is altered to Section 324 IPC and the sentence is reduced to the period of incarceration already undergone
label: RATIO

text: As far as Vettri Vetrivell A 3 Narayanan A5 and Srinivasan A9 are concerned we find no reason to interfere with the judgment of the High Court as each has been held guilty for the offence which they have committed
label: RATIO

text: 10 In view of the above the appeal of Accused Nos 1 3 5 and 9 is dismissed and the appeal of Accused No 2 is allowed and his 1 1997 7 SCC 41 conviction is altered from offence punishable under Section 302 IPC to offence punishable under Section 324 IPC and the sentence is reduced to the period of incarceration already undergone
label: RPC

text: 11 AccusedAppellant Nos 1 2 were granted bail vide this Court s order dated 08 01 2018
label: RPC

text: In view of the above bail bond of Appellant No 1 A1 is cancelled
label: RPC

text: He shall be taken into custody forthwith to serve remaining period of the sentence and bail bond of Appellant No 2 A2 is discharged
label: RPC

text: Pending application s if any stand s disposed of
label: RPC

text: J Deepak Gupta J Aniruddha Bose
label: NONE

text: New Delhi September 27 2019
label: NONE

text: PETITIONER BED RAJ Vs RESPONDENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: THE STATE OF UTTAR PRADESH
label: PREAMBLE

text: DATE OF JUDGMENT 28 09 1955 BENCH
label: PREAMBLE

text: BOSE VIVIAN BENCH BOSE VIVIAN JAGANNADHADAS B SINHA BHUVNESHWAR P CITATION 1955 SCR 2 583 1955 AIR 778 ACT Sentence Enhancement of By the High Court Principles applicable thereto HEADNOTE A question of sentence is a matter of discretion and it is well settled that when discretion has been properly exercised along accepted judicial lines an appellate court
label: PREAMBLE

text: should not interfere to the detriment of an accused person except for very strong reasons which must be disclosed on
label: PREAMBLE

text: the face of the judgment
label: PREAMBLE

text: In a matter of enhancement there should not be interference when the sentence passed imposes substantial punishment
label: PREAMBLE

text: Interference is only called for when it is manifestly inadequate
label: PREAMBLE

text: In the circumstances and bearing all the considerations of the present case in mind it was impossible to hold that the Sessions Judge did not impose a substantial sentence The Supreme Court set aside the sentence imposed by the Court and restored that of the Sessions Judge as no adequate reason bad been assigned by the High Court for considering the sentence passed by the Sessions Judge as manifestly inadequate
label: PREAMBLE

text: Dalip Singh v State of Punjab 1954 S C R 145 and Nar Singh v State of Uttar Pradesh 1956 1 S C R 238 referred to
label: PREAMBLE

text: JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No 88 of 1954
label: NONE

text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 7th January 1954 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No 377 of 1953 connected with Criminal Revision No 461 of 1953 arising out of the Judgment and Order dated the 17th November 1952 of the Court of Additional Sessions Judge at Meerut in Session Trial No 113 of 1952
label: NONE

text: B B Tawakley K P Gupta with him for the appellant
label: NONE

text: K B Asthana and C P Lal for the respondent
label: NONE

text: September 28
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by
label: NONE

text: BOSE J
label: NONE

text: The only
label: FAC

text: question here is about sen tence
label: FAC

text: The appellant Bed Raj and another Sri Chand were jointly charged with the murder of one Pheru
label: FAC

text: The Sessions Judge convicted Bed Raj under section 304 Indian Penal Code and sentenced him to three years rigorous imprisonment
label: RLC

text: He acquitted Sri Chand
label: RLC

text: I Bed Raj appealed to the High Court and that Court on admitting the appeal for hearing issued notice to the appellant to show cause why the sentence should not be enhanced
label: RLC

text: The appeal and the revision were heard together
label: RLC

text: The appeal was dismissed and the High Court enhanced the sentence to ten years
label: RLC

text: Now though no limitation has been placed on the High Court s power to enhance it is nevertheless a judicial act and like all judicial acts involving an exercise of discretion must be exercised along well known judicial lines
label: FAC

text: The only question before us is whether those lines have been observed in the present case
label: FAC

text: The facts that have been found by the Sessions Judge and accepted by the High Court are to be found in the opening paragraph of the learned Sessions Judge s judgment
label: FAC

text: They are as follows Roop Chand the son of Bed Raj accused was removing the dung
label: FAC

text: of the bullocks of Pheru deceased from an open space near his cattle shed
label: FAC

text: Pheru protested to the boy and turned down the basket in which the boy had put the dung
label: FAC

text: The two accused who are brothers then came to the scene from their own cattle shed which was near by and there was an exchange of abuses between them and Pheru
label: FAC

text: The accused Sri Chand then caught hold of Pheru by the waist and Bed Raj accused took out a knife and stabbed him in 3 or 4 places
label: FAC

text: The knife was then left sticking in the neck of the deceased and the accused ran away
label: FAC

text: The assault occurred about 8 o clock on the morning of the 23rd February 1952
label: FAC

text: Pheru was removed to the hospital and the Medical Officer Dr Fateh Singh examined him and found that he was suffering from shock
label: FAC

text: He found three injuries on his person all simple
label: FAC

text: He gave the following description of them right side lower part
label: FAC

text: 2 Incised wound 1 x 1 3 X1 3 right deltoid region frontal and lower part above downward
label: FAC

text: 3 Incised wound 1 2 X 1 6 X 1 4 Epigastric region
label: FAC

text: He said When Pheru was admitted in the hospital he was under shock but his condition was not dangerous
label: FAC

text: When Pheru came he could speak
label: FAC

text: He was not unconscious
label: FAC

text: As he was under shock no report was made for recording his dying declaration
label: FAC

text: I cannot give the definite cause of death
label: FAC

text: I cannot tell if sucH an InjurY can cause death
label: FAC

text: There was no Haemorrhage from Pheru s neck after his arrival in my hospital
label: FAC

text: Speaking of the inJurieis the doctor said Injuries 2 and 3 on the person of Pheru which were incised wounds were not punctured
label: FAC

text: It was not possible to inflict them from a sharp pointed weapon
label: FAC

text: The appellant was also examined by the doctor and a slight simple injury which could have been caused by a simple blunt weapon was discovered
label: FAC

text: This indicates that there was a scuffle between the appellant and the deceased in which the appellant was hit over the nose and up to a point bears out what the appellant says in his defence namely that Pheru was beating the appellant s son Rup Chand he went there and tried to extricate Rup Chand Pheru started beating him the appellant and he the appellant received a flat blow on the nose
label: FAC

text: The depth of the injury on Pheru s neck was I of an inch
label: FAC

text: In this connection the doctor says A knife can penetrate 1 1 2 or 2 inches in a case of deliberate stabbing
label: FAC

text: Pheru died about 12 45 A M on the 24th February 1952 that is to say about 16 or 17 hours after the assault
label: FAC

text: The post mortem was conducted by another doctor Dr J K Dwivedi
label: FAC

text: Describing the injury on the neck the only one we need consider as the other two were slight he said that clotted blood was present all round injury No 1 and that the right side dome of pleura is punctured under injury No 1 and clotted blood present all round it
label: FAC

text: Upper lobe of right lung appex is punctured for 1 4 X 1 4 X 1 2
label: FAC

text: Clotted blood present over the lung surface all round the punctured area
label: FAC

text: A branch of the external jugular vein was divided in right side neck under injury No I
label: FAC

text: Death was due to shock and haemorrhage as a result of injury to neck
label: FAC

text: In cross examination he said It was possible and impossible also that the bleeding could be stopped
label: FAC

text: Such injury as injury No I are more likely to cause death
label: FAC

text: After reviewing the evidence the learned Sessions Judge held It is evident that the whole scene took just a few moments
label: RLC

text: Both of the accused must have been in a moment of heat and before either of them could think of doing any act the whole thing was over
label: RLC

text: That the injuries with the knife were likely to cause death is clear but they were caused at a time when the parties were in a heat and there was a sudden fight and no room for premeditation
label: RLC

text: Because of this and seeing that there was no reason to infer pre concert he acquitted the other accused and by reason of those circumstances he considered that three years would be sufficient punishment and sentenced the appellant accordingly
label: RLC

text: This was on 17 11 1952
label: FAC

text: The appellant filed an appeal to the High Court on 1 8 12 1952 and that Court thereupon issued notice to him to show cause why the sentence I should not be enhanced
label: FAC

text: The High Court directed enhancement on 7 1 1954
label: FAC

text: On the same day the State Government ordered the release of the appellant on probation under section 2 of the U P Prisoners Release on Probation Act 1938 for the full term of the sentence imposed by the Sessions Court
label: FAC

text: We are not concerned with the State Government s order except in so far as it indicates the view that that Government took of the antecedents and conduct in prison of the appellant matters that are also relevant for consideration by a Courtwhen determining a question of sentence a prisoner can only be released on probation under that Act if the State Government is satisfied from his antecedents and his conduct in the prison that he is likely to abstain from crime and lead a peaceable life if he is released from prison
label: ANALYSIS

text: These facts were not known to the High Court when it made its order of enhancement but it is a matter relevant for our consideration now that the appeal is before us
label: ANALYSIS

text: Now the High Court accept the findings of the Sessions Judge about the circumstances in which the offence took place
label: ANALYSIS

text: They agree that the attack was not premeditated and that there was a sudden quarrel and that the blows were inflicted in the heat of passion
label: ANALYSIS

text: They also say that there was counter abuse and they notice the abrasion on the appellant s nose
label: ANALYSIS

text: Despite this they hold that it is possible that this injury was received by the appellant in the attempt of the deceased to resist the attack made by the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: There was therefore no fight
label: ANALYSIS

text: This is a very half hearted finding and ignores the fact that the benefit of all doubts must be given to the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: If it was only possible that the injury was due to Pheru s attempt to ward off an attack by the appellant then it must be equally possible that it was received in the course of a scuffle
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant very definitely says in his examination that there was a fight and the abrasion on his nose which the doctor says was caused by a blunt weapon bears out his version that Pheru struck him with his fist
label: ANALYSIS

text: The circumstances also indicate that there must have been a scuffle
label: ANALYSIS

text: Why else should it be necessary for the second accused to come and hold him down by the waist
label: ANALYSIS

text: When villagers or any man for that matter come to blows after hot words and an interchange of abuse there is nearly always resistance to the initial attack
label: ANALYSIS

text: Very rarely does a man turn the other cheek
label: ANALYSIS

text: It must also be remembered that the incident started with the use of force by Pheru
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was he who took hold of the basket of cow dung andoverturned it
label: ANALYSIS

text: That occasioned the quarrel and the finding is that there was abuse and counter abuse
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was then that the second accused rushed in and caught Pheru by the waist
label: ANALYSIS

text: That accused was acquitted because there was nothing to suggest that that was done in aid of the appellant s intention to assault Pheru and he was absolved of all intention to assault on his own account and the finding is that even the appellant had no such intention till the last moment
label: ANALYSIS

text: If that was the case then why should the second accused rush in and hold Pheru by the waist
label: ANALYSIS

text: If he had no intention to assault on his own account and none to assist the appellant in his assault the only other reasonable conclusion is that he tried to stop a fight
label: ANALYSIS

text: It would be fair in the circumstances to reach that conclusion for the accused is as much entitled to the benefit of any doubt when a co accused is acquitted as in any other case
label: ANALYSIS

text: In any case it was incumbent on the High Court to reach a more definite finding than the one given before deciding to enhance the sentence
label: ANALYSIS

text: The only reason that the learned Judges give is that Pheru was unarmed and as the attack was made with a knife it cannot be said that the appellant did not act in a cruel or unusual manner
label: ANALYSIS

text: Nevertheless they uphold the finding that the offence falls under section 304 Indian Penal Code and not under section 302
label: ANALYSIS

text: A question of a sentence is a matter of discretion and it is well settled that when discretion has been properly exercised along accepted judicial lines an appellate court should not interfere to the detriment of an accused person except for very strong reasons which must be disclosed on the face of the judgment see for example the observations in Dalip Singh v State of Punjab 1 and Nar Singh v State of Uttar Pradesh 2
label: PRE_RELIED

text: In a matter of enhancement there should not be interference when the sentence passed imposes substantial punishment
label: RATIO

text: Interference is only called for when it is manifestly inadequate
label: RATIO

text: In our opinion these principles have not been observed
label: RATIO

text: It is 1 1954 S C R 145 156 2 1955 1 S C R 238 241 impossible to hold in the circumstances described that the Sessions Judge did not impose a substantial sentence and no adequate reason has been assigned by the learned High Court Judges for considering the sentence manifestly inadequate
label: RATIO

text: In the circumstances bearing all the considerations of this case in mind we are of opinion that the appeal which is limited to the question of sentence should be allowed and that the sentence imposed by the High Court should be set aside and that of the Sessions Court restored
label: RPC

text: Ordered accordingly
label: RPC

text: REPORTABLE IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA
label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CRIMINAL APPEAL NO 1193 OF 2011 CHANDRU CHANDRASEKARAN APPELLANT S
label: PREAMBLE

text: Versus STATE REP
label: PREAMBLE

text: BY DEPUTY SUPERINTENDENT OF POLICE CB CID AND ANR
label: PREAMBLE

text: RESPONDENT S WITH
label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL
label: PREAMBLE

text: APPEAL NO 253 OF 2019 SLP CRL NO 2306 OF 2011
label: PREAMBLE

text: J U D G M E N T
label: PREAMBLE

text: Deepak Gupta J
label: NONE

text: 1 Leave granted in appeal arising out of SLP Crl No 2306 of 2011
label: FAC

text: 2 Both the appeals are being disposed of by a common judgment
label: FAC

text: 3 The undisputed facts are that the deceased Arun was a friend of accused Siva Sivaprakash Accused No 1
label: FAC

text: The deceased along with Accused No 1 and Chandru Chandrasekaran Accused No 2 travelled to Chennai on 30 10 2004
label: FAC

text: They went to Meena Guest House run by M Sheik Davood PW3 at about 9 p m where room no 203 was allotted to them
label: FAC

text: At about 9 30 p m Venkatesh Venki came to the room
label: FAC

text: Venki injected 4 ml of Tidijesic drug into the left wrist of deceased Arun
label: FAC

text: Venki also used 2 ml drug for himself
label: FAC

text: Thereafter Venki left the guest house
label: FAC

text: Next morning i e on 31 10 2004 the two appellants herein called Venki since Arun did not get up
label: FAC

text: The room boy of the lodge viz Sankar PW4 complained to the Manager of the lodge that a lot of people were coming into room no 203
label: FAC

text: It was found that Arun was dead
label: FAC

text: Thereafter Iqbal PW2 working as Manager in the company owned by father of the deceased Arun and Ponsekar PW1 maternal uncle of the deceased came to the room
label: FAC

text: 4 PW1 filed a complaint on 31 10 2004 at 9 45 a m in which he stated that his nephew Arun was earlier studying in an engineering college at Chennai
label: FAC

text: However he was not studying properly and had developed some bad habits and therefore he was shifted to a college at Thoothukudi
label: FAC

text: The relevant portion of the complaint is to the effect that on 31 10 2004 at about 7 30 a m he had received a call from Iqbal PW2 informing him that his nephew Arun who stayed the night in Room No 203 of Meena Guest House had consumed heavy dose of a drug through injection and is unconscious
label: FAC

text: He immediately went to the guest house where he found that his nephew was dead
label: FAC

text: He thereafter went to Triplicane Police Station and lodged the report
label: FAC

text: 5 On the basis of the aforesaid report a case being Crime No 1150 of 2004 was registered
label: FAC

text: The body of the deceased was sent for postmortem
label: FAC

text: Dr A N Shanmugham PW6 conducted the postmortem
label: FAC

text: He stated that he could not say with certainty what was the cause of death but it was possible by drug injection
label: FAC

text: Venki was arrested in connection with the said crime and he allegedly made a confessional statement to the police on 08 11 2004 which led to the discovery of Tidijesic syringe empty ampoules unused Tidijesic ampoule etc
label: FAC

text: PW1 the maternal uncle of the deceased filed a petition in the High Court of Madras in February 2005 seeking transfer of the investigation to some other agency since he was not happy with the manner in which the case was being investigated
label: FAC

text: The High Court vide order dated 28 02 2005 transferred the investigation to the CB CID Tamil Nadu
label: FAC

text: There were three suspects before the police viz Venkatesh Venki Sivaprakash Siva and Chandrasekaran Chandru
label: FAC

text: All three were subjected to Polygraph Brainmapping and Narcoanalysis tests at a Forensic Science Laboratory
label: FAC

text: According to the Investigating Officer DW4 who carried the investigation the two appellants herein cleared the said tests and there was no suspicion against them since they disclosed no signs of deception
label: FAC

text: However during the tests Venki s answers were found deceptive
label: FAC

text: 6 In the year 2006 PW5 father of the deceased filed a petition in the Madras High Court for transferring the investigation of the case to the Central Bureau of Investigation CBI
label: FAC

text: This petition was rejected by the High Court on 08 02 2008
label: FAC

text: Meanwhile on 23 01 2008 more than three years after the incident a chargesheet was filed by the CB CID under Section 173 of the Criminal Procedure Code for short CrPC only against Venkatesh Venki under Section 304 Part II of the Indian Penal Code for short IPC
label: FAC

text: The present accused appellants herein were cited as prosecution witnesses in the said chargesheet
label: FAC

text: Venki died after the filing of the chargesheet but before trial of the case on 21 07 2008 7
label: FAC

text: It was only thereafter that PW1 maternal uncle of the deceased filed a private complaint before the court which is Exhibit P1
label: FAC

text: In this complaint it was stated that the two accused and the deceased had stayed in Room No 203 and Venki came to the room at the invitation of the accused Chandru
label: FAC

text: Venki was a drug peddler and Arun was not in the habit of taking drugs
label: FAC

text: On the request of the accused Venki had injected 4 ml of Tidijesic injection in the left wrist of the deceased
label: FAC

text: It was also alleged that Venki was paid Rs 50 by the accused Siva for his services
label: FAC

text: According to this complaint Arun had been injected for the second time in the left arm inner portion
label: FAC

text: When this witness went to the room No 203 Venki was present and told the complainant that the accused had given excess narcotic drugs on the left inner portion of the arm due to which the deceased died
label: FAC

text: In the complaint it was also stated that immediately after he had visited the guest house on 31 10 2004 he had gone to the Triplicane Police Station where the police forcibly obtained his signatures on two blank papers
label: FAC

text: It was alleged that the FIR was lodged by the police in connivance with the two accused
label: FAC

text: In this complaint it is also mentioned that there were marks of injecting two injections and according to the report of the Forensic Science Laboratory a huge amount of narcotic substance had been injected into the deceased which caused his death
label: FAC

text: In this complaint it was also alleged that the accused Siva had close association with PW10 hereinafter referred to as R
label: FAC

text: According to the complainant R PW10 was introduced to the deceased Arun and they used to regularly talk to each other on phone every day and therefore accused Siva could not tolerate that his girlfriend should shift loyalty to some other person
label: FAC

text: Therefore he approached Chandru who was a student in a medical college and with his help injected excess dose of Tidijesic with the intention of killing Arun
label: FAC

text: 8 After the filing of the private complaint the metropolitan magistrate recorded the statements of seven witnesses and found sufficient grounds for proceeding with the case under Section 302 IPC
label: FAC

text: Thereafter the case was committed to the Court of Sessions and charges were framed against the accused who pleaded not guilty
label: FAC

text: The evidence of the witnesses were recorded
label: FAC

text: Accused also examined four witnesses
label: FAC

text: The trial court convicted the accused for having committed the offence punishable under Section 302 IPC read with Section 120B IPC and sentenced them to undergo life imprisonment
label: RLC

text: Aggrieved the accused filed two separate criminal appeals which have been dismissed
label: FAC

text: Hence the present appeals
label: FAC

text: 9 Admittedly there are no eyewitnesses to the case and this is a case based on circumstantial evidence
label: ANALYSIS

text: The law with regard to appreciation of circumstantial evidence has been clearly enunciated in the case of Hanumant v State of Madhya Pradesh1 wherein this Court held as follows 10 It is well to remember that in cases where the evidence is of a circumstantial nature the circumstances from which the conclusion of guilt is to be drawn should in the first instance be fully established and all the facts so established should be consistent only with the hypothesis of the guilt of the accused
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Again the circumstances should be of a conclusive nature and tendency and they should be such as to exclude every hypothesis but the one proposed to be proved
label: PRE_RELIED

text: In other words there must be a chain of evidence so far complete as not to leave any reasonable ground for a conclusion consistent with the innocence of the accused and it must be such as to show that within all human probability the act must have been done by the accused
label: PRE_RELIED

text: 10 This law has been consistently followed and has been repeated in catena of authorities
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is not necessary to refer to all the authorities
label: ANALYSIS

text: However we may refer to Sir Alfred Wills book Wills on Circumstantial Evidence Chapter VI 2 in which he has laid down the following Rules specially to be observed in the case of circumstantial evidence RULE 1 The facts alleged as the basis of any legal inference must be clearly proved and beyond reasonable doubt connected with the factum probandum 1 AIR 1952 SC 343 2 Butterworths Seventh Edition Pp 296 329 RULE 2 The burden of proof is always on the party who asserts the existence of any fact which infers legal accountability RULE 3
label: ANALYSIS

text: In all cases whether of direct or circumstantial evidence the best evidence must be adduced which the nature of the case admits RULE 4
label: ANALYSIS

text: In order to justify the inference of guilt the inculpatory facts must be incompatible with the innocence of the accused and incapable of explanation upon any other reasonable hypothesis than that of his guilt
label: ANALYSIS

text: RULE 5
label: ANALYSIS

text: If there by any reasonable doubt of the guilt of the accused he is entitled as of right to be acquitted
label: ANALYSIS

text: 11 The law can be summarised in the following terms 1 The circumstances relied upon by the prosecution which lead to an inference to the guilt of the accused must be proved beyond doubt 2 The circumstances should unerringly point towards the guilt of the accused 3 The circumstances should be linked together in such a manner that the cumulative effect of the chain formed by joining the links is so complete that it leads to only one conclusion i e the guilt of the accused 4 That there should be no probability of the crime having been committed by a person other than the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: 12 It is in the light of the aforesaid law that we have to consider the evidence and the circumstances relied upon by the courts below
label: ANALYSIS

text: 13 In a case based on circumstantial evidence it is always better for the courts to deal with each circumstance separately and then link the circumstances which have been proved to arrive at a conclusion
label: ANALYSIS

text: Unfortunately in this case though a reference has been made to some circumstances the circumstances have not been discussed separately
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore we propose to discuss the various circumstances relied upon by the prosecution 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: LAST SEEN TOGETHER
label: ANALYSIS

text: As far as this circumstance is concerned the same stands proved
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is the case of all that Room No 203 in Meena Guest House was hired by the two accused and the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: Venki came at about 9 30 p m but he left at 10 15 p m Thereafter the lodge was locked
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore this circumstance is proved
label: ANALYSIS

text: Though this circumstance is proved we must also look into the circumstances under which the accused were last seen together with the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: The case of the prosecution is that it is the accused who took the deceased to the room with the intention of killing him since the accused Siva suspected that R PW10 was having an affair with the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: However the manner in which the accused reached Chennai and the guest house in question suggests a total different story
label: ANALYSIS

text: The maternal uncle of the deceased PW1 states that one Jeyaraj an employee of PW5 informed him over the phone at about 6 7 p m on 30 10 2004 that the deceased Arun along with his friend Siddharth was coming to stay in the night with PW1 at Chennai
label: ANALYSIS

text: A few minutes later PW1 talked to his nephew Arun who also told him that he would be coming to his uncle s house but did not come
label: ANALYSIS

text: Siddharth is the son of Gomti Pandian PW7
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to her Siddharth told her that he was going to Chennai along with his friend Arun deceased to purchase some clothes
label: ANALYSIS

text: She was reluctant to send her son with his friend but then she talked to Arun who told her that they would be going to Chennai by bus and convinced her to send Siddharth with him
label: ANALYSIS

text: She dropped Siddharth at the bus stand
label: ANALYSIS

text: Later she came to know that her son Siddharth had gone to Chennai along with the deceased Arun and three other persons in a car which had met with an accident
label: ANALYSIS

text: She was informed about this by Kala Devi PW8 whose son Mathesh had also travelled in the same car
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus it is clear that it was Arun deceased who convinced Siddharth s mother to send Siddharth with him
label: ANALYSIS

text: This witness also stated that later her son informed her that the car had met with an accident and thereafter he and Mathesh did not proceed to Chennai and returned to their homes
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW8 states that her son Mathesh had told her that he was going to Coimbatore
label: ANALYSIS

text: Next morning she received a call from her brother s son
label: ANALYSIS

text: He told her that the car in which Mathesh was travelling had met with an accident
label: ANALYSIS

text: She was also told that Mathesh along with his friends Siva Chandru Siddharth and Arun came to the house of her brother and thereafter Mathesh returned to home
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus it is clear that Siddharth and Mathesh were also travelling in the car and they would have also gone to Chennai but for the fact that the car met with an accident
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thereafter Siddharth and Mathesh did not proceed further and returned to their homes
label: ANALYSIS

text: As such it is clear that it was not the accused who had organised the trip but it was the deceased who had organised the trip and therefore it cannot be said that the accused had taken the deceased to the guest house with the intention of killing him
label: ANALYSIS

text: This assumption by both the courts below is based on no evidence
label: ANALYSIS

text: 2 MEDICAL EVIDENCE
label: ANALYSIS

text: Medical evidence led in this case clearly indicates that the deceased died due to overdose of Tidijesic
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is not disputed that 4 ml of Tidijesic was injected into the wrist of the deceased by Venki who administered 2 ml of the same substance into himself and thereafter the deceased died
label: ANALYSIS

text: The evidence of Dr R Baskaran PW11 who is Professor and Head of the Department of Legal and Forensic Medicines Royapettai Government Hospital Chennai clearly shows that after chemical analysis it was found that the amount of the offending substance found in the blood of the deceased would be equal to injecting 40 ml of Tidijesic
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore there is no manner of doubt that the deceased died due to overdosing of drug
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW11 stated that if a 20 ml syringe is used then about 40 ml of Tidijesic could be injected in two attempts
label: ANALYSIS

text: However if a 5 ml syringe is used it would require 810 attempts
label: ANALYSIS

text: He clearly states that he cannot tell when and how this 40 ml Tidijesic was injected into the body of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: He also could not state what time the death had occurred
label: ANALYSIS

text: He also stated that it takes 6 to 24 hours for the drug to take effect and this would further depend upon the quantity of the drug the physique and the actions of the person injected
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore his statement does not help us with regard to the time of death or with regard to the number of attempts in which the drug was injected into the body of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even in the postmortem report the approximate time of death has not been indicated
label: ANALYSIS

text: Dr A N Shanmugham PW 6 who conducted the postmortem also could not say when the death took place
label: ANALYSIS

text: Dr A N Shanmugham PW6 in his statement had stated that injuries caused by the needle due to injection of medicine were found in fore arm ankle of front foot front and middle fore arm
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has been confronted with the post mortem report PD5 in which there is mention of only two injection marks one in front of left elbow joint and one in middle of left fore arm
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is clearly mentioned that no other external or internal injuries seen over the body
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has not been able to give a proper explanation why he did not mention other injuries in the postmortem report
label: ANALYSIS

text: This would mean that the deceased was injected only twice
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is the case of the prosecution that on the first occasion the deceased was injected with 4 ml Tidijesic
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore 36 ml could not have been injected in one go on the next occasion
label: ANALYSIS

text: The police has not recovered any syringe or other material from the room
label: ANALYSIS

text: As per the prosecution case the lodge was locked at about 10 30 p m
label: ANALYSIS

text: The next morning the deceased was found dead
label: ANALYSIS

text: No recoveries of any ampoules or syringe have been made from the accused or at their instance to connect them with the offence
label: ANALYSIS

text: The prosecution by means of the aforesaid medical evidence has failed to link the accused with the death of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: The prosecution has failed to prove the exact time of death of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: The deceased was first injected an injection between 9 30 p m to 10 00 p m
label: ANALYSIS

text: As per doctor the effect of this could end in about six hours
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore the possibility of the deceased getting up himself in the middle of the night to inject himself cannot be ruled out
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is also the possibility of his calling some other person to inject him with the drug
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even more importantly the prosecution has failed to prove where the balance 36 ml of drug came from
label: ANALYSIS

text: Who got this drug and when
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no evidence that the accused purchased this drug
label: ANALYSIS

text: No recovery has been made from them and therefore we are of the view that though it stands proved that the deceased died due to overdose of drug the prosecution has miserably failed to link the accused with the death of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: 3 MOTIVE
label: ANALYSIS

text: The motive put forth is that R PW10 was close to accused Siva who introduced her to Arun
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to the case set up by the prosecution the two had developed a close relationship and were regularly chatting with each other on phone and through SMSes
label: ANALYSIS

text: This was not liked by Siva Accused No 1 who thereafter conspired with Chandru Accused No 2 to kill the deceased by overdosing him
label: ANALYSIS

text: R PW10 in her statement has not at all supported the prosecution case and according to her she had never met Arun but had talked to him over phone and that too occasionally
label: ANALYSIS

text: She also stated that she and the deceased Arun would exchange SMSes which were usual in nature
label: ANALYSIS

text: She in crossexamination denied the suggestion that she used to talk to Arun every day
label: ANALYSIS

text: She stated that they talked generally about matters relating to college
label: ANALYSIS

text: She also denied that she had any special relationship with Siva
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to her Siva was her friend being a collegemate
label: ANALYSIS

text: No other evidence has been led to prove that R PW10 had any special relationship with accused Siva or that she had developed any special relationship with deceased Arun
label: ANALYSIS

text: The only evidence in this regard is the statement of R PW10 which does not support the prosecution case at all
label: ANALYSIS

text: In this regard it would also be pertinent to mention that in the first complaint filed by PW1 there is no mention of R PW10 much less of her having any affair with either the accused or the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: This was brought out for the first time only in the complaint filed four years after the death of Arun
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no explanation for this long silence of four years
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore we are clearly of the view that the motive has not been proved
label: ANALYSIS

text: We must also remember that the accused and the deceased were good friends
label: ANALYSIS

text: They had studied for many years together and there is not even an iota of evidence about such love triangle
label: ANALYSIS

text: 4 CHANDRU WAS A MEDICAL STUDENT
label: ANALYSIS

text: Both the courts below have come to the conclusion that Chandru was asked by Siva to commit the crime because Chandru was a medical student and he alone knew how to inject the substance into the body of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: We are constrained to observe that the inference drawn by the courts below was totally ill founded
label: ANALYSIS

text: Why would Chandru kill another human being just on the asking of the accused Siva
label: ANALYSIS

text: Chandru was a medical student studying in a profession meant to save lives and not to kill people
label: ANALYSIS

text: From the evidence on record it stands established that the deceased was a drug addict and had been taking injectible drugs for a long time
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is well known that such drug addicts can easily inject themselves
label: ANALYSIS

text: What has happened in this case is not clear but it cannot be said with certainty that Chandru had injected the poisonous substance into the body of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no evidence in this regard
label: ANALYSIS

text: As we have discussed above it was not only Siva and Chandru who were coming to Chennai with deceased Arun but Siddharth and Mathesh were also coming to Chennai in the same car
label: ANALYSIS

text: However they went back only after the car met with an accident
label: ANALYSIS

text: All these boys were in their late teens or early 20s and two of them got scared after the accident and they went to the homes of their relatives and from there they contacted their respective mothers
label: ANALYSIS

text: Since they had obtained permission of their mothers by giving false excuses they got scared and went back
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even as per the prosecution Chandru had no motive to kill Arun
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore the inference drawn by the High Court as well as the trial court that Siva and Chandru had conspired or had the common intention of murdering Arun is not based on any cogent or reliable evidence
label: ANALYSIS

text: 14 Other than the circumstances referred to above there are other circumstances which go against the prosecution which we shall refer to now 1 Inconsistency in the statement of PW1 PW1 is the maternal uncle of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: In his first complaint made in the police station on 31 10 2004 there is no reference to R PW10 or other facts which have been stated at a later stage
label: ANALYSIS

text: The private complaint filed by him four years later is contrary to the first complaint filed by him immediately after the occurrence
label: ANALYSIS

text: His explanation is that he was asked to sign on two blank papers by the police
label: ANALYSIS

text: First of all we see no reason why the police in a case of this nature would try to help the accused and shield the actual criminal
label: ANALYSIS

text: Secondly there is no material on record to show that PW1 the maternal uncle or PW 5 father of the deceased ever complained to any authority that PW1 had been forced to sign two blank papers
label: ANALYSIS

text: This is a case where the maternal uncle and the father of the deceased had approached the High Court on at least two occasions for transfer of the investigation
label: ANALYSIS

text: They succeeded once and failed on the second occasion
label: ANALYSIS

text: In case the version of PW1 that his signatures were taken on blank papers was correct then he would have definitely said so much earlier
label: ANALYSIS

text: He would have reported the matter to the higher authorities or made mention of this in the petitions filed in the High Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: Despite a pointed query to the counsel for the original complainant and the informant and the State they failed to point out whether any such complaint had been made by PW1 or PW5
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore we do not accept the version of PW1 that his signatures were obtained on blank sheets of papers
label: ANALYSIS

text: This also casts a doubt on the veracity of the statement of PW1
label: ANALYSIS

text: 2 Delay in filing the private complaint
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is true that PW1 and PW5 were moving the High Court for transfer of the case to some other investigating agency but at the same time it would be pertinent to mention that after the chargesheet was filed against Venki by the Investigating Officer DW4 neither PW1 nor PW5 filed any protest petition to the effect that the accused appellants herein should also be arraigned as accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: They let the matter go on and it was only after Venki died that the private complaint was filed
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no explanation why no protest petition was filed when the police had only made out a case against accused Venki and that too under Section 304 IPC and not murder
label: ANALYSIS

text: 3 PW1 and PW5 are not coming to the Court with clean hands
label: ANALYSIS

text: The motive has been introduced after four years
label: ANALYSIS

text: The father and the maternal uncle of the deceased never brought up the issue of the deceased having conversations with R PW10 at any earlier stage
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore PW1 and PW5 are not coming to the court with clean hands
label: ANALYSIS

text: They have cooked up the story of signing on blank papers and also cooked up the story relating to the motive
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore their evidence is not reliable and a person cannot be convicted on the basis of such evidence
label: ANALYSIS

text: 15 All that is proved is that the deceased and the accused were sleeping in one room and the deceased died due to overdose of drug
label: RATIO

text: The prosecution had miserably failed to prove that the accused injected this drug
label: RATIO

text: It is the case of the prosecution that the first injection was administered by Venki which was only 4 ml
label: RATIO

text: There is possibility of the deceased injecting himself on the second occasion sometime in the middle of the night or early in the morning
label: RATIO

text: In this context we must remember that the doctor who conducted the postmortem has not given any approximate time of death of the deceased which could have helped us in the matter
label: RATIO

text: The circumstances proved cannot lead to the inference that it is the accused alone who committed the offence
label: RATIO

text: In fact the prosecution has even failed to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the death is homicidal in view of the inconsistencies in the medical evidence dealt by us above
label: RATIO

text: Even otherwise it is not proved that it was the accused who injected the deceased and the possibility of the accused injecting himself or some other person doing so cannot be ruled out
label: RATIO

text: 16 In view of the above discussion we allow both the appeals set aside the judgment dated 30 11 2010 of the High Court in Criminal Appeal No 592 of 2010 and 636 of 2010 and judgment dated 24 09 2010 of the Additional District and Sessions Judge Fast Track Court No V Chennai in S C No 237 of 2009
label: RPC

text: The accusedappellants are acquitted
label: RPC

text: They are directed to be released immediately unless required in any other case
label: RPC

text: Pending application s if any stand s disposed of
label: RPC

text: J SANJAY KISHAN KAUL J DEEPAK GUPTA
label: NONE

text: New Delhi February 12 2019
label: NONE

text: PETITIONER SUBHASH ANOTHER Vs RESPONDENT STATE OF U P DATE OF JUDGMENT06 05 1976
label: PREAMBLE

text: BENCH CHANDRACHUD Y V BENCH CHANDRACHUD Y V SARKARIA RANJIT SINGH SHINGAL P N CITATION 1976 SCR 587 1976 AIR 1924 1976 SCC 3 629 ACT Code of Criminal Procedure S 374 Reference for confirmation of death sentence whether High Court obliged to examine entire evidence independently HEADNOTE Ram Sanehi received two gun shot wounds on his chest and died within ten minutes
label: PREAMBLE

text: Two of his children claimed to have witnessed the occurrence
label: PREAMBLE

text: The dead body was subjected to post mortem only after about 24 hours had elapsed
label: PREAMBLE

text: The same evening appellant Subhash surrendered and appellant Shyam Narain was arrested though for another offence altogether
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Sessions Court convicted them under s 302 I P C and sentenced Subhash to death and Shyam Narain to imprisonment for life
label: PREAMBLE

text: The accused moved the High Court in appeal while the Sessions Court referred the matter to it under s 374 for confirmation of the death sentence
label: PREAMBLE

text: The question before this Court was whether in the case of such references the High Court was obliged to examine the entire evidence independently
label: PREAMBLE

text: Allowing the appeal the Court HELD
label: PREAMBLE

text: On a reference for confirmation of the sentence of death the High Court is under an obligation to proceed in accordance with the provisions of sections 375 and 376 of the Criminal Procedure Code
label: PREAMBLE

text: The High Court must not only see whether the other order passed by the Sessions Court is correct but it is under an obligation to examine the entire evidence for itself apart from and independently of the Sessions Court s appraisal and assessment of that evidence
label: PREAMBLE

text: 589A B Jumman and Ors v The State of Punjab AIR 1957 S C 460 Ram Shanker Singh and Ors v State of West Bengal 1962 Supp 1 SCR 49 at 59 and Bhupendra Singh v The State of Punjab 1968 3 SCR 404 followed
label: PREAMBLE

text: JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION
label: NONE

text: Criminal Appeal No
label: NONE

text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated 27 11 74 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No 2646 73 and Referred No 95 73
label: NONE

text: Frank Anthony E C Agarwala and A T M Sampath for the Appellants
label: NONE

text: O P Rana for the Respondent
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by CHANDRACHUD J
label: NONE

text: The appellants Subhash and Shyam Narain were convicted by the learned Civil and Sessions Judge Farrukhabad under section 302 of the Penal Code on the charge that at about 9 a m on June 9 1972 they committed the murder of one Ram Sanehi
label: RLC

text: Subhash was sentenced to death and Shyam Narain to imprisonment for life
label: RLC

text: The judgment of the trial court having been confirmed in appeal by the High Court of Allahabad the two accused have filed this appeal by special leave of this Court
label: RLC

text: The case of the prosecution is briefly as follows on the morning of June 9 1972 the deceased Ram Sanehi had gone to his field along with his son Bal Kishore and his daughter Kusuma Devi for eating Kharbuzas
label: FAC

text: While they were returning from the field at about 9 a m the appellants who were lying in wait near a culvert suddenly accosted Ram Sanehi
label: FAC

text: The Appeallent Subhash pointed the barred of his gun towards the chest of Ram Sanehi and said that since he Ram Sanehi was a witness against him in a complaint filed by Pooran Lal and since he was also doing Pairvi on behalf of Pooran Lal he would not be allowed to remain alive
label: FAC

text: The appellant Shyam Narain was armed with a lathi
label: FAC

text: Bal Kishore and Kusuma Devi pleaded with the appellants to spare their father but Shyam Narain asked Subhash not to delay the matter and finish Ram Sanehi quickly
label: FAC

text: Subhash thereupon fired three shots from his double barrelled gun the last of which misfired
label: FAC

text: Ram Sanehi fell down whereupon the appellants dragged him by his legs over a distance of 6 or 7 paces
label: FAC

text: Bal Kishore and Kusuma Devi then raised an alarm whereupon Brij Bhusan Shyam Lal Mangali Prasad and Jhabbo Singh Thakur reached the place of occurecnce and challenged the appellants
label: FAC

text: Before running away the appellant Subhash told his companion Shyam Narain that he on his own part was going to surrender before a court and that Shyam Narain should make his own arrangements
label: FAC

text: Ram Sanehi died within about 10 minutes after receiving the injuries
label: FAC

text: Bal Kishore first went to his house which is at about a distance of 120 yards from the scene of offence
label: FAC

text: At about 12 o clock at noon he went to the Kamalgani police station and lodged his First Information Report Ex Ka 3
label: FAC

text: S I Vishwanath Sharma who was posted as a 2nd officer at the police station recorded Bal Kishore s complaint
label: FAC

text: went to the scene of occurrence prepared the inquest report and handed over the dead body for being sent for post mortem examination to the District Hospital at Farrukhabad which is about 10 miles away form the village of Kandharpur where the incident took place
label: FAC

text: S I Sharma took samples of earth from the place of occurrence an seized a mis fired cartridge which was lying concealed in the folds of the deceased s Dhoti
label: FAC

text: The Fard in that behalf is Ex Ka 10 and the site plan is Ex Ka 11
label: FAC

text: The appellant Subhash surrendered before the Additional District Magistrate Judicial at Farrukhabad at about 4 p m on the very day
label: FAC

text: The appellant Shyam Narain was arrested at about 2 40 p m on the same day under section 122 of the Railway Act for crossing The railines at Fatehgarh
label: FAC

text: The appellants denied the charge that they had committed the murder of Ram Sanehi and stated that they were involved in the case due to enmity
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: This defence has been rejected both by the Sessions Court and the High Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: Before referring to the evidence in the case it has to be mentioned that the High Court had before it not only the appeal filed by the accused but also a reference made by the Sessions Court for confirma tion of the capital sentence under section 374 of the Code of CriminalProcedure
label: ANALYSIS

text: Time and again this Court has pointed out that on a reference for confirmation of the sentence of death the High Court is under an obligation to proceed in accordance with the provisions of sections 375 and 376 of the Criminal Procedure Code
label: ANALYSIS

text: Under these sections the High Court must not only see whether the order passed by the Sessions Court is correct but it is under an obligation to examine the entire evidence for itself apart from and independently of the Sessions Court s appraisal and assessment of that evidence
label: ANALYSIS

text: From the long line of decisions which have taken this view it would be enough to refer to the decisions in Jumman and ors v The State of Punjab Ram Shanker Singh ors v State of West Bengal and Bhupendra Singh v The State of Punjab
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The High Court has failed to show due regard to this well established position in law
label: ANALYSIS

text: It did not undertake a full and independent examination of the evidence led in the case and it mainly contented itself with finding out whether the Sessions Court had in any manner erred in reaching the conclusion that the charge of murder levelled against the appellants was established beyond a reasonable doubt
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court is right in saying that the main question in the case was whether Bal Kishore and Kusuma Devi who were examined as eye witnesses were truthful witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: But then it did not subject their evidence to any minute scrutiny
label: ANALYSIS

text: Impressed overbearingly by the circumstance that the Sessions Court had the opportunity of observing the demeanour of the witnesses the High Court apparenty thought that such an opportunity gave to the Sessions Court s judgment a mystical weight and authority even though the learned Sessions Judge had not in his judgment or while recording the evidence made any special reference to the demeanour of the witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court accepted the evidence of Ram Sanehi s children by observing that there was no material contradiction ill their evidence and that certain statements in the F I R afforded a guarantee that the two witnesses were present when their father was done to death
label: ANALYSIS

text: We will now proceed to show how several significant circumstances either escaped the attention of the High Court or were not given their due and rightful importance
label: ANALYSIS

text: First as to the manner in which S I Sharma conducted investigation into the case
label: ANALYSIS

text: The offence took place at about 9 a m on June 9 and though the District Hospital at Farrukaabad was just 10 miles away the dead body was not received at the hospital for nearly 24 hours after the incident had taken place
label: ANALYSIS

text: The excuse offered by the prosecution that cartman was not willing to take the body at night is utterly flimsy because the Investigating officer could have easily made some alternate arrangement for despatchin the dead body for postmortem examination expeditiously
label: ANALYSIS

text: With the dead body lying at the scene of offence for nearly 12 hours and thereafter at the police station for another 8 or 9 hours it was easy enough for the witnesses to mould their statements so as to accord with the nature of injuries
label: ANALYSIS

text: The lnvestigating Officer did not make any note at all in the General Diary as to which witnesses were examined by him on the date of the occurrence which was obligatory upon him to do under paragraph 44 of the U P Police Act
label: ANALYSIS

text: The time when the investigation was commenced and the time when it was concluded are not mentioned in the case diary
label: ANALYSIS

text: The time when the Investigating officer reached the village and the time when he returned to the police station are also not noted in the case diary
label: ANALYSIS

text: S I Sharma stated in his evidence that several important facts concerning the investigation were being stated by him in his evidence from memory
label: ANALYSIS

text: He reached the scene of offence at about 2 30 p m but it was not until about 6 p m that he inspected the site
label: ANALYSIS

text: The dead body was not removed from the scene of offence till about 9 p m and even that is open to grave doubt because the Investigating officer has admitted in his evidence that he was unable to say as to when the dead body was taken way from the spot and whether it was taken directly to the hospital or was detained somewhere on the way
label: ANALYSIS

text: He was unable to say whether it was right or wrong that the dead body remained in the village till about 4 O clock on the morning of the 10th
label: ANALYSIS

text: Forty or fifty persons had gathered at the scene of offence when the Investigating officer arrived but the record of the case does not show that the statement of any of those persons was ever recorded
label: ANALYSIS

text: In fact even the statement of Kusuma Devi was recorded late at night for which the reason is stated to be that her elder sister Pushpa Devi died of shock on the evening of the 9th after hearing of her father s murder
label: ANALYSIS

text: It may be that Pushpa Devi died on the 9th but apart from the cause of her death the statement of Kusuma Devi need not have been held up so long
label: ANALYSIS

text: We are doubtful if the Investigating officer at all knew on the 9th that Pushpa Devi had died
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has admitted that his knowledge in that behalf was derived from hearsay reports
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant Subhash had surrendered before the Additional District Magistrate Farrukhabad on the afternoon of the 9th itself while the other appellant Shyam Narain was arrested at Fatehgarh at about 2 40 p m
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Investigating officer did not even know of these significant developments though they had taken place just a few miles away from the scene of investigation
label: ANALYSIS

text: He says that he learnt of the surrender and the arrest of the appellants on the evening of the 12th
label: ANALYSIS

text: Mangali Prasad has been examined by the prosecution as an eye witness and his name is mentioned in the F I R as one of the four persons who arrived at the scene of offence even before the appellants had run away
label: ANALYSIS

text: His statement was recorded 11 days later on June 20
label: ANALYSIS

text: The F I R mentions expressly that the appellants caught hold of the legs of the deceased and started dragging him
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Investigating officer has not stated in the Panchnama of the scene of offence whether the ground was soft or hard or sandy which had great relevance on the allegation that the deceased was dragged over a certain distance
label: ANALYSIS

text: Finally it is surprising that the Investigating officer did not think it worthwhile to pay a visit to the field where the deceased is alleged to have gone with his children for eating Kharbuzas
label: ANALYSIS

text: Indeed he stated that he was not in a position to say if there were Kharbuzas at all in the field when the occurrence took place
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court has condoned these lapses on the part of the Investigating officer with the observation that he appears to have been inexperienced and somewhat negligent
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Investigating officer has stated in his evidence that he had put in 7 years of service
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is difficult to understand on what basis the High Court attributed the lapses on his part to mere inexperience
label: ANALYSIS

text: We will presently indicate the significance of the various lapses and loopholes in investigation but to say as the High Court has done that the Investigating Officer was somewhat negligent seems to us in the circumstances a grave euphemism
label: ANALYSIS

text: We will now proceed to deal with the various circumstances which in our opinion render it unsafe to accept the prosecution case
label: ANALYSIS

text: Dr S C Pandiya who performed the post mortem examination has described in his evidence the injuries received by Ram Sanehi
label: ANALYSIS
